0.text: Holofernes and Nathaniel discuss Don Armado, with whom Nathaniel has been conversing. They mock his inferior intellect, criticizing his pronunciation and saying that they abhor 'such rackers of orthography' . Armado, Moth, and Costard enter; Armado tells the learned men that the King has asked him to prepare 'some delightful ostentation, or show, or pageant, or antick or firework'  to entertain the Princess and her party. He asks Holofernes and Nathaniel for their help in planning this entertainment, and Holofernes suggests that they present a show of the Nine Worthies. The men discuss who will play the roles of the Worthies, with Holofernes saying that he will play three of the roles himself. They then go off to plan their show.

2.text: Fortunatus and Nathaniel discussed Danmato. Danmato engaged in conversation with them. They chuckled at Danmato's low intelligence, grumbled about his mispronunciation, and disapproved of 'such distorted character people.' Danmato, bean curd, and Costade arrived. Danmato informed the scholars that the prince desired him to arrange 'some delightful decorations, be it performances, plays, or oddities, or fireworks' for the princess and her escort's amusement. He requested Holfernes and Nathaniel's assistance in planning this entertainment. Holfernes proposed a presentation of the nine great heroes. They deliberated on who would portray the heroic roles, and Holfernes declared he would assume three roles himself. Subsequently, they departed and initiated their preparations for the performance.

4.text: Danmato and Nathaniel discussed Danmato. Danmato took part in their conversation. They laughed at Danmato's low IQ and mocked his pronunciation, but they didn't like 'such diverse types of humans.' Danmato, Tofu, and Costello arrived. Danmato informed the scholars that the prince was willing to arrange 'some kind of delightful decoration, be it performance, drama, or something strange, or fireworks' for the princess and her companion for enjoyment. He requested the help of Holfernes and Nathaniel in planning this performance. Holfernes proposed the performance of the Nine Heroes. They discussed who would take on the hero roles, with Holfernes claiming he would play three of them. In the end, they left and began preparing for the performance.

6.text: Danmatuo and Natemlo discussed Danmatuo. Danmatuo took part in their conversation. They chuckled at Derp.io's low IQ, mocked Danmatuo's pronunciation, but disliked 'such diverse types of humans.' Danmatuo, Tofu, and Costello arrived. Danmatuo told the scholars that the prince is willing to prepare 'entertaining decorations, be it performances, plays, or anything strange' for the queen and her companion. He requested Holfernes and Natemlo's assistance in planning this performance. Holfernes suggested performing the deeds of the nine heroes. They discussed which role each person should take, and Holfernes claimed he would take on three. In the end, they left and began preparing for the performance.

0.text: Jim and the Harling children feel the happiest and most content that spring just playing in the garden. They do not yet know that the summer will change everything. In the beginning of summer, some Italians come into town and set up a dancing pavilion in a vacant lot. They begin giving dancing lessons to children, and people start to gather and congregate around the lot. Now there is something for people to do and somewhere for them to socialize. Dancing becomes a city-wide craze, and every Saturday night there is a late-night dance. Jim goes all the time, as do many girls and boys from the country. At this point, Antonia, Lena, and Tiny become known as 'the hired girls' and are always at the dances too.

2.text: Janus and Jaring's children are happiest and most contented only in the spring, playing in the garden. They had not anticipated that changes would come with the summer. In the early summer, a group of Italians entered the city and built a pavilion on an empty plot of land. They began teaching the children to dance, and people started gathering and concentrating there. Now there is a social and business hub. Dancing became the most popular trend in the city, with a grand ball every Saturday night. Janus regularly attended, and many rural little girls and boys came to participate. At this time, Antonia, Lenna, and the little ones were called 'hired girls,' and they were always present at the balls.

4.text: January and Jarin's children are happiest only in spring, contentedly playing in the garden. They didn't imagine or expect changes when spring gave way to summer. In the early summer, Italians gathered in the city and built pavilions on open ground. They began teaching dance to the children. People gathered and focused intently. Now, that place is the center of social and commercial activities. Dance is the most popular trend in the city. Every weekend there is a large dance party. Jarin always attends, and country girls and boys also gather. At that time, Antonia, Lenna, and the children were called 'hired girls' and were always present at the dance parties.

6.text: In the spring, January and Jarin's children are most content in the garden, basking in their own time carefree. They hadn't foreseen or anticipated any changes that summer would bring. Early summer sees Italians flocking to the cities to construct pavilions. They commence teaching dance to children. The crowd gathers, focused on this spot. Now, it is the heart of city life and commercial endeavors. Dance is the city's latest craze. Weekly, grand dance events take place. Jarin is always in attendance, along with rural girls and boys. At that time, Antonia, Lenna, and the children were referred to as 'hired girls,' consistently present at the dance events.

8.text:
In the spring, Jani and Jalin's children enjoy their most pleasant time in the garden, feeling the most pleasant weather. The changes brought by summer were unexpected and unforeseen by them.

In early summer, the Italians quickly rushed to the city to build pavilions. They began teaching children to dance, and then gathered here. Now, this place has become the core of city life and business. Dancing became the latest trend in the city. There is a large-scale dance event every week. Jalin often accompanies country girls and boys. At that time, Antonia, Lenna, and their children were called 'hired girls,' and they regularly attended dance events.

10.text:
In the spring, Jin and Jelin's children enjoy their most enjoyable moment in the garden when they feel the most comfortable weather. The change of seasons came suddenly.

At the beginning of summer, the Italians hurried to the city to build a Loggia. Children gathered there, and it became the center of city life and business. The stage was set for the latest urban trend. Every week, large-scale dance events were held. Jelin was called a 'maid' back then, and she always participated in the dance events with the boys and girls of the country. At that time, Antonia, Liana, and those children were also called 'maids.' They attended the dance events every week.

(Translation from Chinese to English:)
在春季，ジン和ジェリン的孩子在園中最喜歡的moment是感受到最舒服的天氣時間。季節突然到來了。

夏季開始時，意大利人匆匆奔跑到市中，開始建造 Лодʒія 。孩子們聚集在那裡，那裡成為了城市生活和業務的中心。舞台上出現了最新的城市趨勢。每週大規模的舞會會舉行。ジェリン被稱為「雇妹」，她一直參加了那些舞會。那時，安托尼ア、リアナ等孩子們也被稱為「雇妹」。每週參加舞會。

13.text:
In the spring, Jin and Jin-lin's children enjoy the pleasant weather together in their favorite garden section. Suddenly, this season arrived.

At the beginning of summer, the Italians urgently came to the city to build Loggias. Children gathered there, becoming the city's center of life and business. The latest city trends have already been built. Weekly parties were held. Jin was called a 'servant,' and from then on, she attended these parties every week. At that time, Antonia, Regina, and others were also called 'servants.' They all attended the parties every week.

Weekly celebrations ensued. Jin was named a 'helper,' and from then on, she attended these celebrations each week. At that time, Antonia, Regina, and others were also named 'helpers.' They all attended these celebrations each week.

0.text: Elizabeth reads through Darcy's letter with a mixture of emotions. When she first reads Darcy's explanation of his conduct with Bingley and Jane, she dismisses his explanation of his concern about Jane's indifference as false, and believes he acted solely because of her family. However, when she begins reading his explanation of the dealings with Wickham, she begins to read more clearly. She soon begins to realize that she had not known anything of Wickham before the night when he told her of he and Darcy, and she wonders why she didn't realize his impropriety at speaking of such things to a stranger. As she continues to reread and think, she realizes that she had been 'blind, partial, prejudiced, absurd,' and that she believes Darcy's version of what happened. She then rereads the section about Jane and Bingley, and sees that she cannot deny the justice of his description of Jane's seeming indifference after all. After two hours of wandering in the park she returns home to be told that both Fitzwilliam and Darcy had come to say their good-byes

2.text: In reading Darcy's letter, Elizabeth's emotions were complex. At first, she did not believe Darcy's explanation of Jane's and Bingley's behavior towards Elizabeth, thinking it was merely due to her family connections. But when she came across matters relating to Wickham, she read more carefully. She soon realized she knew nothing about Wickham before the night he was mentioned to her, and pondered why she had failed to notice his inappropriateness. As she reread and thought, she acknowledged her previous blindness, bias, prejudice, and folly, and came to believe Darcy's account. She then re-read the section on Jane and Bingley and acknowledged the truth in his description of Jane's apparent indifference. After two hours of strolling in the park, she returned home to find that Fitzwilliam and Darcy had come to bid farewell.

读 Darcy 的信时，她对德利感到复杂的情感。初始她不信任 Darcy 对 Филен的行为，认为它归因于他们家庭背景。但是，当她遇到与 Филен汉有关的事情时，她更小心地阅读。很快，她 realization 她对 Филен汉一无所知，那晚他告诉她这一点，让她思考为什么她没有注意到他不适当的行为。通过进一步阅读和思考，她承认了她的 ignorance, prejudice, 和笨拙，并信任 Darcy 的描述。两小时后，她去了公园散步，回到家时发现克威和 Darcy 准备离开。

0.text: Falstaff and Bardolph appear on a public road near Coventry, followed by a newly enlisted company of soldiers. Sir John orders Bardolph to replenish his supply of sack and to tell Peto to meet him at the town's end. He dislikes the idea of marching his men through the town in their rags and tatters. Abjectly impoverished, not one of them could pay him, as so many others had, for release from military service. In Falstaff's own words, 'No eye hath seen such scarecrows' . Prince Hal and Westmoreland meet him on the road and comment on the poor creatures whom Falstaff leads. The knight remains undisturbed and is philosophical in the face of this criticism. And, for that matter, the prince seems amused rather than indignant. All are to make haste, says Hal, for Percy is already in the field.

Here's the English translation of the given Chinese text:

Falstaff and Badoulf appeared near Coventry with a new troop of soldiers. Sir John instructed Badoulf to re-equip his bag, telling Peterson to wait for him at the end of the city. He didn't like leading these ragtag soldiers through the city. No one could pay him, just like many others trying to leave military service. Falstaff himself also remarked, 'No one has ever seen such a hideous face.' Prince Hal and Westmoreland encountered him on the road and reprimanded Falstaff for leading those pitiful people. The knight remained unperturbed and kept a calm demeanor. In fact, the prince seemed more amused than angry. Everyone needed to hurry, according to Hal, as Percy was already on the battlefield.

0.text: Now that he has felt the pain of losing his son, Siddhartha has more sympathy with the needs and desires of ordinary people. He again decides to seek his son in the town, but stops when he thinks he hears a special message from the river. He remembers when he rebelled against his own father, and realizes that his father must have suffered the same pain as he, Siddhartha, suffers now. Sorrows repeat themselves. Still suffering, he returns to the hut and tells Vasudeva of his troubles. Vasudeva, in his silent attentiveness, seems to Siddhartha like a god. They both go and sit by the river bank. Siddhartha practices his technique of listening to the river and realizes the unity of all life amidst all its diverse elements. He realizes that in the unity is perfection. His pain disappears as his Self merges with the unity. From that moment on, Siddhartha no longer fights against his destiny. He accepts everything. Vasudeva, now that he has seen his friend attain enlightenment, announces that he is leaving. He is going to live in the woods and be in the unity of all things.

2.text:
At this moment, he felt the pain of losing his child deeply, as Siddhartha came to understand the desires and needs of common people even more. He decided to search for his son in the city, but when he heard a specific message, he came to a halt. He recalled the moments of resistance against his father, realizing that his father too must endure the same pain, as Siddhartha did. The pain repeated. Still in a painful state, he returned to the bed and told Vasudeva about his condition. Vasudeva, seeming deep in thought like a deity, sat down with Siddhartha by the river. Siddhartha practiced the art of listening to the water, achieving the unity of all life. He succeeded. His pain disappeared because he merged his self into the unity. From then on, Siddhartha no longer resisted fate. He accepted everything. Vasudeva, seeing his friend attain Nirvana, announced his departure. He was going to live in the forest, in the unity of all things.

Translation:

At this moment, he deeply felt the pain of losing his child, and Siddhartha came to understand the desires and needs of ordinary people even more. He decided to search for his son in the city, but when he heard a specific piece of news, he came to a stop. He recalled the moments of resistance against his father, realizing that his father too must endure the same pain, as Siddhartha did. The pain repeated. Still in a painful state, he returned to the bed and told Vasudeva about his situation. Vasudeva, appearing deep in thought like a god, sat down with Siddhartha by the riverbank. Siddhartha practiced the art of listening to the water, achieving the unity of all life. He succeeded. His pain disappeared because he merged his self into the unity. From then on, Siddhartha no longer resisted fate. He accepted everything. Vasudeva, seeing his friend attain Nirvana, declared his departure. He was going to live in the forest, in the unity of all things.

4.text:
At this moment, he deeply felt the pain of losing his son, Sidartha deeply understood the desires and needs of common people. He decided to search for his son in the city, but when he heard certain news, he paused. He recalled his past resistance towards his father, and the pain resurfaced. Still in a painful state, he told Vasudeva about his situation. Vasudeva, after deep thought, sat down beside Sidartha by the river. Sidartha practiced listening in the water and achieved the unity of life. Success. His pain disappeared because he merged with the unity of life. From then on, Sidartha no longer resisted fate. He accepted everything. Vasudeva, seeing his friend attain Nirvana, announced his departure. He was going to the forest to live in harmony with all material things.

此时刻，他深深地感受到了失去儿子的痛苦， Sidartha 深刻地了解到平常人的欲望和需要。他决定在城市搜寻他的儿子，但当他听到某些消息时，他停顿了。他回忆了过去对父亲的反抗， realization of his father likewise enduring the same pain. The pain resurfaced. Still in a painful state, he told Vasudeva about his situation。 Vasudeva，深思熟虑，坐下来旁边 Sidartha 河边。 Sidartha 在水中练习听法，实现了生命的统一。成功。他的痛苦消失了，因为他融入了生命的统一。从那以后，Sidartha 再也不反抗命运。他接受了一切。 Vasudeva，见 friend 得到涅槃，宣布离开。他要去森林，与所有物品共处。

6.text: At this moment, Sidartha pondered deeply, sitting by the riverbank next to Vasudeva. Sidartha practiced listening in the water, achieving the unity of life. He was successful. His suffering vanished because he merged into the unity of life. From then on, Sidartha no longer resisted fate. He accepted everything. Seeing his friend attain Nirvana, Vasudeva announced his departure. He planned to live in the forest in harmony with all material things.

8.text: At this moment, Sadatha deeply pondered, sitting by the riverbank next to Vasudeva. In the water, Sadatha practiced listening, obtaining the unity of life. He succeeded. Sadatha's suffering vanished, merging into the unity of life. From then on, Sadatha no longer resisted fate. He accepted all. After friend's attainment of Nirvana, Vasudeva declared to leave. He intended to live harmoniously with all material things in the forest.

10.text: At this moment, Saratas pondered deeply, sitting by the riverbank with Vasudeva. In the water, Saratas practiced listening, obtaining the unity of life. He succeeded. Saratas' hardships vanished, merging into the unity of life. From then on, Saratas no longer resisted fate. He accepted all of it. Vasudeva obtained the shallow pool of the Nile, and declared his departure. He intended to live in harmony with all the materials in the forest.

13.text:
In this place, there were countless thoughts of Saraswati. She sat by the river edge, alongside Vasudeva. In the water, Saraswati practiced her listening skills, attained the unity of life. She succeeded. Saraswati's problems vanished, merged into the unity of life. From then on, Saraswati no longer resisted fate. She accepted everything. Vasudeva obtained the shallow pool of the Nile River, declared his departure. He intended to live harmoniously with all forest materials.

Saraswati's issues disappeared, merged into the unity of life. From then on, Saraswati no longer defied fate. She surrendered to it all. Vasudeva obtained the Nile River's shallow pool, announced his departure. He planned to live in harmony with all forest resources.

20.text:
Here is the English translation of the Chinese text:

25.text: In this place, Saraswati's thoughts ran deep. By the Narayani River, she stood next to Vasudeva. In the expansive tranquility of this wide river, Saraswati meticulously sharpened her intuition, achieving the unity of life. She had succeeded. Saraswati's issues vanished, merging into the unity of life. From then on, Saraswati no longer opposed her destiny. She relinquished all. Vasudeva, by the Narayani River, obtained a shallow pool and announced his departure. He longed to live in harmony with all the forest's beings.

She succeeded. Saraswati's problems disappeared, merging into the consistency of life. From then on, Saraswati no longer resisted fate. She let go of everything. Vasudeva, owning the Narayani Riverbank, obtained a shallow pool, representing the fulfillment of his wishes. He longed for all beings in the forest to coexist peacefully.

0.text: Salisbury, Pembroke, and Lord Bigot come onstage. The battle is still raging. The dudes can't believe that King John's forces are still standing strong. That said, they thinks it's awesome that King John had to leave the battle with a doctor's note. Just then, in comes the French Count Melun, who's trying to hold his guts so they don't fall out of his body. Melun tells the English lords to abandon their rebellion and swear allegiance to King John once more, because if the French and the rebels defeat King John, Louis the Dauphin plans to have all his English allies beheaded. At first, Salisbury can't believe him. But then Melun explains that he is about to die, anyway, and he'll get a better reward in heaven by telling the truth now than by keeping mum. Anyway, he explains, his grandfather was English, so he has some sympathy for them. Salisbury definitely doesn't want to get his head lopped off, so he decides to believe Melun. Salisbury and the other English nobles leave the stage, taking Melun with them.

2.text:
Sir Salisbury, Pembroke, and the adults entered. The battle was still ongoing. They could not trust the strength of the John forces. But they believed that the doctor's proof that John had left the battlefield was cool. Suddenly, Count Maolnic appeared. He tried to grab his stomach to prevent bleeding. Melun told the English nobles to give up resistance and submit to John again, just like France and the resistance forces had defeated John, Ludlow Forty-Four Plan was to subjugate all English allied forces.

At first, Sir Salisbury harbored doubts about him. But Maolnic explained that telling the truth in heaven would bring more rewards, so Sir Salisbury decided to believe Maolnic. Sir Salisbury and the other English nobles left the stage with Maolnic.

4.text:
Sir Salisbury and Pembroke, along with other English gentlemen, entered. The fight was still going on. But they didn't trust Caesar's military strength. However, they trusted the doctors' proof that Caesar had left the battlefield, making the battlefield peaceful and orderly. Suddenly, Marlnik appeared. He tried to press on Caesar's abdomen to stop the bleeding. Melvin told the English gentlemen to give up resistance, to surrender to Caesar again, just like the French and the resistance had defeated Caesar, Nelson's forty-four plan was to suppress all the forces of the English Alliance.

At first, Sir Salisbury had doubts about Marlnik. But Marlnik explained that truth-telling in heaven brings more rewards, so Sir Salisbury decided to trust Marlnik. Sir Salisbury and other English gentlemen left the stage with Marlnik.

However, they trusted the doctor's confirmation that Caesar had left the battlefield, making the battlefield peaceful and orderly. Suddenly, Marcellus appeared. He tried to press on Caesar's abdomen to stop the bleeding. Marcellus told the English gentlemen to give up resistance, surrender to Caesar once again, just like the French people had already defeated Caesar.

At first, Sir Salisbury was suspicious of Marcellus. But Marcellus explained: 'Truth comes from heaven and brings greater rewards, so Sir Salisbury decided to trust Marcellus.' Sir Salisbury and the other English gentlemen left the stage with Marcellus.

0.text: There is much speculation at the training college when Sue does not return that evening at prayer time. Everyone wonders about the young man she has gone out with, and some of them are convinced that Jude is only posing as her cousin. The situation takes a serious turn because a similar incident occurred the year before: a young man had managed to seduce a student of the same college, maintaining that he was her cousin. The mistress inquires about the two photographs on Sue's dressing table. One is of Mr. Phillotson, and the other is of an unknown undergraduate. The next morning, when Sue does return, she is punished and kept in solitary confinement. The other students feel the punishment is too harsh and prepare to protest. In the evening it is discovered that Sue has escaped from a back window. She turns up at Jude's place. She is soaked and shivering with cold. Jude immediately takes her in and offers her some dry clothes and brandy. Sue is so tired that she falls asleep while relating her story.

2.text:
Sue's absence during prayer time at the training college in the evening sparks much speculation among the students. They ponder over the young man she has gone out with, and some suspect Jude is only pretending to be her cousin. The situation becomes serious as a similar incident occurred the previous year: a young man had seduced a student from the same college, claiming to be her cousin. The headmistress inquires about the two photographs on Sue's dressing table. One is of Mr. Phillotson, and the other is of an unknown undergraduate. The next morning, Sue finally returns and is punished, kept in solitary confinement. The other students feel the punishment is too harsh and prepare to protest. In the evening, it is discovered that Sue has escaped from a back window. She shows up at Jude's place, soaked and shivering with cold. Jude immediately takes her in, offers her some dry clothes and brandy. Sue is extremely tired and falls asleep while narrating her story.

In English:

They wonder about the young man she has been seen with, and some suspect Jude is only pretending to be her cousin. 0.text: Hamilton defends the treaty-making procedures outlined in the Constitution. He responds to the criticism that the Constitution wrongly mixes the legislative and executive branches of government by affording both a role in making and approving treaties. Hamilton argues that act of treaty-making does not fit neatly into the typical purview of either the executive or legislative branch. Therefore, affording a role to both is appropriate. Other critics claimed that the power to make treaties should be limited to the president. Hamilton responds that, unlike European monarchs, the president is only in office for a limited period of time. He may therefore be tempted to sign a treaty detrimental to the nation but beneficial to his private interests since he will eventually return to being a private citizen . It is therefore necessary that his power be held in check by the legislature. Others asserted that the Congress should have even greater authority over treaty making. However, Hamilton responds that this would introduce unnecessary delays and inefficiencies to the process and weaken the American negotiating position.

2.text: Hanilon defended the constitutional convention process in the Constitution. He responded to the criticism that the Constitution confused legal and administrative power in the convention process, as both branches can participate in the convention and approval. Hanilon argued that the convention-making process is not suitable for the usual administrative or legal branches. Therefore, the appropriate role allocation is necessary. Some people believe that the power to make treaties should be limited to the presidency. Hanilon countered, unlike European monarchies, the president's term is limited. He might sign harmful treaties for the national interest but beneficial for his personal interest, but eventually, he would become an ordinary citizen. Therefore, the power to check him lies with the legislative branch. However, some argue that the legislative branch should have more treaty-making power. But Hanilon countered, this would introduce unnecessary delays and inefficiency and weaken the American negotiating position.

0.text: Linda and Mrs. Bruce go off on vacation, and Linda experiences plenty of ugly prejudice, even though she's working as a nurse for Mrs. Bruce's child. Like: The waiters won't give her tea when she's eating with Mrs. Bruce. She's not allowed to sit in a chair and hold the child on her lap, but has to place the child in the chair and stand behind her. The servants won't bring her dinner to her room when Mrs. Bruce asks them to, so she has to go down to the kitchen to get it herself. Finally, Linda puts her foot down and says that Mrs. Bruce is paying for her just like any of the white servants, so she'd better be treated like one of them. This actually works. See, Linda says, you've just got to stand up for your rights.

2.text: Lin Da and Madam Du went on a trip, with Lin Da taking care of Madam Du's children. However, she often encountered ugly prejudice, despite being Madam Du's nurse. For instance, waiters would not serve her tea, they ate dinner in the same room. She was not allowed to sit on chairs with her children, instead, she had to put the children on the chairs and stand behind them. The waiters would not bring food to her room, she had to fetch it herself. In the end, Lin Da drew a line and told Madam Du, 'You must assert your rights.' Surprisingly, it worked. Lin Da said, 'You should be treated with respect, just like a white colleague.'

0.text: After Leon had gone, Emma began a period of secret mourning. She drifted about aimlessly and was often melancholy. In her misery, she began again the strange and unpredictable behavior that had marked her in Tostes. Her moods constantly changed, and she was often giddy and nervous. One day Rodolphe Boulanger, a handsome and wealthy landowner, brought one of his servants to be treated by Bovary. While there he saw Emma and was immediately attracted by her good looks and ladylike bearing. Boulanger was a suave bachelor, both coarse and shrewd. The duck was startled and asked, 'Maslow, give me a coin.' Maslow gave him a coin. This coin was picked up from the roadside. The duck comforted him and returned the coin, then ran away. Maslow arrived at a village, where the farmers claimed they had seen that person in his car. When he stopped, a beggar appeared. Maslow told Laplace about that mysterious person. Maslow continued his journey, hoping to see M.CHARLES in England.

Malle picked up the coin he had dropped. The child comforted him, returned the coin, and ran away. Malle arrived at a village, where farmers reported they had seen that person on his car. When he stopped, the police appeared. Malle shared this information with Laplas. Malle continued his journey, looking forward to meeting M.CHARLES in England.

0.text: The mayoral election comes up for Zenith, and the left-wing lawyer Seneca Doane is running. That means that Babbitt and his pro-business brotherhood need to fire up their election machine and get anyone other than Doane into office. They promote a candidate named Lucas Prout and Babbitt goes around giving speeches in support of Prout. Ultimately, Babbitt's efforts are able to get Lucas Prout elected mayor. The business community survives another big scare from organized labor. Now that he has an established reputation as a speechmaker, Babbitt is invited to all sorts of functions to give speeches about business and about the glory of Zenith. One of the main points in his speeches is that state universities should fire all professors who preach liberal or socialist views. As his star continues to rise in Zenith's social circles, Babbitt wonders how he ever could have doubted the joys of being a solid citizen.

2.text:
The Zenith city mayor election is approaching, Senior Shenango Dao, a left-wing lawyer, has announced his candidacy. This means that Babbit and his business brothers must activate their voter machine to ensure that no one but Dao becomes the mayor. They promoted a candidate named Jorge Fernandez, Babbit attended a rally in support of Fernandez. In the end, Babbit's efforts helped Fernandez win, protecting the business community from the threat of labor union organizations. Now, due to his oratory skills, Babbit has been invited to various events, here he delivers a beautiful speech about business and Zenith. The core of his speech is criticizing professors with red or socialist ideas at universities. With Babbit's influence in Zenith's social circle continuing to grow, he began to ponder the happiness brought about by the good citizens he had once doubted.

Translation:

The Zenith city mayor election is approaching. Senior Shenango Dao, a left-wing lawyer, has announced his candidacy. This means that Babbit and his business brothers must activate their voter machine to ensure that no one but Dao becomes the mayor. They promoted a candidate named Jorge Fernandez. Babbit attended a rally in support of Fernandez. In the end, Babbit's efforts helped Fernandez win, protecting the business community from the threat of labor union organizations. Now, due to his excellent oratory skills, Babbit has been invited to various events, where he delivers beautiful speeches about business and Zenith. The core of his speech is criticizing professors with communist or socialist ideas at universities. With Babbit's influence in Zenith's social circle continuing to expand, he began to ponder the happiness brought about by the good citizens he had once doubted.

4.text: The Zenith mayoral election is approaching. Senior Shenango Dao announced his candidacy for the position. This means that Babbit and his business brother must rally their voter base to ensure that only Dao becomes mayor. They supported a candidate named Jorge Fernandez. Babbit attended Fernandez's campaign events and played a crucial role in his victory, protecting the business sector from labor union pressure. Currently, Babbit's eloquent speeches have gained him numerous invitations to events. At these events, he passionately discusses business and the beauty of Zenith in his speeches. His main theme is the rejection of university professors promoting red or socialist ideologies. With Babbit's influence in Zenith society growing, he now recalls the happiness brought about by the virtuous citizens he once doubted.

6.text: The Zenith mayor election is approaching. Sprintano old man declared his intention to run for mayor. This means that Babbit and his business brothers need to consolidate their power to ensure Dao becomes the mayor. They previously supported a candidate named Jorge Fernandes. Babbit participated in Fernandes' election campaign and made significant contributions to his victory, protecting the business world from the labor union's influence. Currently, Babbit's influence in Genesis society is expanding. At the meeting, he spoke passionately about business and the beauty of Genesis. Another significant message is his denial of the spread of red ideologies and socialism in Genesis society. Babbit recalls the regret he had for the kind-hearted people he once doubted as his influence in Genesis society grows.

8.text: The Zenith city chair election is approaching. Sprintano Mr. expresses his intention to join the city chair race. This means that Babbit and his business brothers need to rally their forces to ensure that their candidate wins. They previously supported a candidate named Jorge Fernandes. Babbit participated in Fernandes' campaign and made significant contributions to his victory, protecting the business community from the influence of the labor union. At the meeting, Babbit passionately spoke about business and the beauty of Genesis and its original myth. Another important piece of news is his denial of the spread of communist thoughts and socialism in Genesis society. Babbit still regrets those who had doubted his integrity in Genesis society, and his influence continues to grow.

10.text: The Zenithcity mayor election is upcoming. Sprinto Mr. has declared his intention to run for mayor. This signifies that Babbit and his business brothers must rally their forces to secure the victory of their candidate. They had previously backed Jefferson Fernandes. Babbit took part in Fernandes' campaign and made substantial contributions to his win, shielding the business community from labor union intervention. During the gathering, Babbit eloquently discussed business and the allure of Genesis and its original myth. A significant piece of information is his rejection of the proliferation of Marxist ideologies and socialism in Genesis society. Babbit still laments the suspicion he faces from some members of Genesis society, but his sphere of influence continues to broaden.

0.text: The next day, Sue, having changed her mind as usual, writes Jude a note saying he must not come to Shaston. Jude writes back agreeing not to meet her. But on Easter Monday he gets a message from Mrs. Edlin saying that his aunt's health is sinking. Jude rushes to Marygreen to find Aunt Drusilla already dead. He informs Sue, who arrives for the funeral. After the funeral, Sue and Jude have a discussion about Aunt Drusilla's disapproval of marriage for the Fawleys. Sue confesses to an intense physical aversion to Phillotson, although she respects and likes him as a friend. Jude senses her unhappiness and laments the fact that he did not try to prevent her hasty marriage. Sue will not let Jude comfort her and goes off to Widow Edlin's cottage for the night. Later that night, Jude hears the cry of trapped rabbit, and, unable to bear it, he goes out and relieves it of further pain by putting it to death. He finds Sue awake at her window, and she breaks down and pours out all her suffering to him. She finally admits her mistake in not considering the full implications of marriage.

2.text:
Starting from that day on, Suzlon frequently changed her mind and wrote to Jude telling him not to go to Charleston. Jude replied immediately and refused to see him. However, on Eastern Monday, Jude received a message from Margaret Morgan. He was informed that Lisle had passed away. He told Suzlon that she had attended the funeral. After the funeral, Suzlon and Jude talked about Falwey's dissatisfied marriage. Suzlon expressed her strong physical discomfort, but respected him as a friend. Jude felt her unease and wanted to prevent her from rushing into another marriage, but was not granted permission. Suzlon refused to be comforted, staying in Widow Edlin's house. One evening, Jude heard a mournful sound, which he thought was that of a mournful rabbit. He decided not to let it worsen, and killed it, ending its suffering. He saw Suzlon crying at the window of Full Moon Inn. She could not console herself.

(Note: In the Chinese translation, the identity of the speaker of the mournful sound was not clear, so I translated it as a rabbit's voice to maintain the original context. However, it's possible that the speaker was actually Suzlon, in which case the translation would be different.)

0.text: Once inside the chateau, in his elegant private rooms, the Marquis prepares for supper and awaits his nephew's arrival. When his nephew -- Charles Darnay -- arrives, the two exchange brief formalities and then, after the servants have left, Darnay tells his uncle that he is renouncing all ties to his family and to France. Although he is coolly polite, the Marquis' dislike for his nephew is apparent. Darnay equally despises his uncle, and the fear and hatred inspired by the Evremond name troubles him. Before they part, the Marquis asks about Darnay's relationship with Doctor Manette and Lucie and then smiles mysteriously. In the morning, the Marquis is discovered dead -- stabbed by a member of the Jacquerie.

2.text:
At the HounDaiGuan Inn, in his elegant private room, Master Hou prepared dinner, waiting for his nephew, Avoo, to arrive. When Avoo came in, they exchanged brief courtesies, and after the servants had left, Avoo informed his uncle that he had severed all ties with his family and France. Despite his cold respect, Master Hou did not love his nephew, and Avoo hated his uncle just as much. Before they parted, Master Hou inquired about Avoo and Doctor Manette and Lucie. He smiled mysteriously.

0.text: As this scene opens, Cyrano is in a state of frenzied exhilaration because Roxane has acknowledged his existence. He wishes to prove his worth to her by showing his valor. Two gentlemen, Cuigy and Brissaille, enter with the drunken Ligniere, who declares that a hundred men are waiting to attack him. Cyrano offers to offer him protection, by escorting him with a troop of officers. He declares, however, that he will find the attackers alone and unaided. As they prepare to leave, several others join the group, wishing to witness what happens at the Porte de Nesle. When they depart, Cyrano is proudly at the head of the group. He pauses to say that it was necessary to send one hundred men to kill Ligniere because everyone knows he is a friend of his, implying that everyone fears Cyrano.

2.text: Cyrano (Duo Lao Nu) encountered Roxanne (Luo Xi) for the first time, realizing his own existence, his heart was agitated and insecure, holding the proof of his worth and the meaning of serving her. Two gentlemen, Qiou Ji and Bi Sa Er, entered with a drunken Lin Jialing (Lin Yi Er), declaring that a hundred men were waiting to attack him. Duo Lao Nu offered protection, intending to lead out a troop. But he declared that he would face the attackers alone. Just as they were about to leave, a few more people joined them, wanting to witness the performance on the stage of D'Artagnan. They left with Duo Lao Nu haughtily leading the way. He paused for a moment, declaring that a hundred men must go and kill Lin Jialing because everyone knew he was his friend, implying that everyone was afraid of Duo Lao Nu.

4.text:
I. Introduction: None

II. Source Text (Chinese):  Cyrano（дуо老ну）首次见到罗欣（Luo Xi），实感自己存在，心情不安，抱着自己的价值证明和为她服务的意义。两位君子，乔锦和比萨二（Qiou Ji 和 Bi Sa Er），带着醉进来的林家令（Lin Yi Er），宣布有百名人等待攻击他。度老ну提供保护，想领出军队。但是他宣布单独面对攻击者。就在离开之际，几位人又加入了，想看到达撒旦舞台上的表演。他们离开，度老ну骄傲地领队。他暂停了一下，宣布百名人必须去杀林家令，因为每个人都知道他是他的朋友，暗指每个人怕度老ну。

III. Target Language (English): Cyrano (Duo Lao Nu) encountered Roxanne (Luo Xi) for the first time, feeling his own existence, his heart was uneasy, holding the proof of his worth and the meaning of serving her. Two gentlemen, Qiou Ji and Bi Sa Er, entered with a drunk Lin Jialing (Lin Yi Er), declaring that a hundred men were waiting to attack him. Duo Lao Nu offered protection, intending to lead out a troop. But he declared that he would face the attackers alone. Just as they were about to leave, a few more people joined them, wanting to witness the performance on the stage of D'Artagnan. They left with Duo Lao Nu proudly leading the way. He paused for a moment, declaring that a hundred men must go and kill Lin Jialing because everyone knew he was his friend, implying that everyone was afraid of Duo Lao Nu.

IV. Translation Explanation: The passage describes a scene from the play 'Cyrano de Bergerac' where Cyrano (Duo Lao Nu) encounters Roxanne (Luo Xi)

When they were about to leave, a few more people joined them, eager to see D'Artagnan perform on stage. They all went out together, and Cyrano proudly led the way. He paused, declaring that a hundred men must kill Lin Yi Er, because everyone knew he was his friend, hinting that everyone was afraid of Cyrano.

0.text: Fire Rises The French countryside lies ruined and desolate. An unidentified man, weary from travel, meets the mender of roads. They address each other as 'Jacques' to indicate their status as revolutionaries. The mender of roads directs the man to the chateau of the murdered Marquis. Later that night, the man sets the castle on fire. A rider from the chateau urges the village soldiers to help put out the fire and salvage the valuables there, but they refuse, and the villagers go inside their homes and put 'candles in every dull little pane of glass. The peasants nearly kill Gabelle, the local tax collector, but he escapes to the roof of his house, where he watches the chateau burn. The narrator reports that scenes such as this are occurring all over France

2.text: A fire occurred, devastating and leaving the French countryside barren. An unidentified man, weary from traveling, met a road worker. They addressed each other as 'Jacques,' signifying they were revolutionaries. The road worker led the man to the chateau of the slain Marquis. That very night, the man ignited a fire in the castle. Knights from the castle begged the villagers for help in putting out the fire and saving its wealth, but they refused, and the villagers returned to their homes, lighting a candle in every dimly lit window. Peasants nearly killed the tax collector, Gabelle, but he escaped to the roof of his house, watching the castle burn. The novelist depicts such incidents as commonplace in France.

4.text: A fire occurred, devastating French farmlands, resulting in barren lands. An unidentified man, weary, met a highway worker. They addressed each other as 'Jacques,' signifying they were revolutionaries. The highway worker guided the man into the earl's manor, which had been murdered. That night, the man lit a fire in the castle, igniting a fire in the castle. The castle knights appealed to the villagers for assistance in quelling the fire and safeguarding their riches, but they declined, returning to their homes, each room illuminated by a solitary candle. The villagers came close to slaying the tax collector, but he managed to evade them, retreating to his residence within the castle, watching it burn from above. The novelist portrayed these happenings as commonplace in France.

6.text: A fire broke out, destroying French farmlands, leaving barren lands behind. A weary man encountered a left-wing worker. They called each other 'Jacques,' signifying they were revolutionaries. The left-wing worker led the man into a mansion, where a murder took place. That night, the man lit a fire in the mansion, causing a mansion fire. The mansion knights appealed to the villagers for help in extinguishing the fire and protecting their wealth, but they refused, returning home instead. Each household was self-sufficient with candles. The villagers attempted to evade the tax collector, but he escaped, returning to the mansion, watching it burn from above. This event is commonly described by novelists in France.

0.text: In the opening chapter, the period in which the novel is set is described. The story begins about fifteen years before the French Revolution. It is a time when many people think they live in the best of times, while others condemn it as the worst of times. The kings of England and France are both mediocre rulers, and they believe in their divine rights. People are put to death for the slightest of crimes. The condition in France is very bad, for there is a total disregard for the common people by the aristocracy; injustice, cruelty, and oppression are rampant. The aristocracy is unaware that the masses are preparing for the revolution by turning timber into guillotines and farm carts into tumbrels to convey people to the guillotine. In England, too, lawlessness and poverty prevail. Even the colonies in America are up in arms against their English rulers, and the attempts of the American colonies to obtain freedom are not taken seriously.

2.text: This novel's opening chapter depicts the novel's setting fifteen years prior to the French Revolution. Some regarded it as the best of times, while others denounced it as the worst. Both the English and French monarchies were governed by mediocre monarchs, relying on their divine right. People were sentenced to death for minor infractions. France's situation was grim, with the nobility indifferent to the plight of the commoners; injustice, cruelty, and oppression were prevalent. The nobility remained oblivious to the masses' impending revolution, converting wood into guillotines, wagons into tumbrels, and transporting people to the guillotine. England grappled with lawlessness and poverty. The American colonies rebelled against English rule, yet their quest for freedom was disregarded.

The French nobility instigated a revolution, transforming carriages into battlefields, the French Revolution's square, and meting out capital punishments; the English turned a blind eye, dismissing the unrest and poverty in the distance. The American colonies nurtured anti-British resistance, but their yearning for freedom was disregarded.

100.text: Fifteen years ago, this novel painted a picture of the ancient French setting. Some saw it as an age of affluence, while others unveiled its concealed allure and enchantment. The English monarchy held onto power through inheritance, pardons for sins, and the pardon of criminals; the French nobility averted their gaze from the toil and hardships of peasants, while the common people suffered under unjust laws and widespread poverty. The French nobility ignited a revolution, transforming battlefields into battlefields and revolution squares into slaughterhouses; the English masses remained composed, witnessing the chaos and destitution from a distance. The American colonies fostered anti-English resistance, but their longing for freedom was disregarded.

0.text: It seems that Rosamond refuses to learn any lessons from her situation; to appease her vanity, she starts to think of Will Ladislaw, and imagines that he must love her instead of Dorothea, because she is so beautiful and charming. She continues to blame her husband for her unhappiness, not her rabid materialism; everything is someone else's fault, and she is still a creature who is perfectly innocent of blame. She gets a letter from Will, saying that he will be paying a visit sometime soon; Rosamond is cheered up by this, and decides to send out invitations for a dinner party. Of course, all invitations are denied, and Rosamond is still ignorant as to the reason why; she goes to visit her parents, and they tell her the terrible news. When she goes home, she tells her husband that she has heard about everything; she then reiterates that they must go to London, to lessen her suffering. He cannot stand to hear this, and storms out, without taking the time to correct her or explain anything.

2.text:
Rosamond seems unable to learn from her own circumstances. To satisfy her arrogance, she compared Ladislau and D'Alvador, believing that her beauty and allure would make them inseparable from her, not the other way around. She continually blamed her wife for the causes of her suffering, apart from Materialism; she had always been a spoiled and flawless object of pampering. She received a letter from Will, informing her of his imminent arrival; Rosamond's spirit was lifted, and she extended invitations for a feast. Unfortunately, all invitations were declined, leaving Rosamond in the dark about the reasons. She visited her parents, who shared distressing news with her. Upon her return home, she informed her husband of everything that had transpired; once again, she demanded they go to London to alleviate her distress.

However, he could not bear this command, and he left in a rage, making no attempt to clarify her misunderstandings or resolve any issues.

She continually blamed her wife for the causes of her suffering, apart from Materialism; she had always been a spoiled and flawless object of indulgence. She received a letter from Will, informing her of his imminent arrival; Rosamond's spirit was lifted, and she extended invitations for a banquet. Unfortunately, all invitations were declined, leaving Rosamond in the dark about the reasons. She visited her parents, who shared distressing news with her. Upon her return home, she informed her husband of everything that had transpired; once again, she demanded they go to London to alleviate her distress.

But he could not bear this command, and he left in a fit of anger, making no attempt to clarify her misunderstandings or resolve any issues.

0.text: As the travelers traverse the length of Utah, a Mormon missionary boards the train and proceeds to give all who will listen to him an odd lesson in Mormon history, practice, theory, and culture. Passepartout is curious at first and joins the lecture, but he manages to escape when he finds it extremely boring. At Ogden the train stops and another Mormon man hurries onto the train, having just had a fight at home. Passepartout asks him how many wives he has and the man answers that he only has one. Passepartout finds this different from the other Mormons and possibly a better idea because having more than one wife can be a hot mess.

2.text: In Utah, a purification priestess boarded the train and began teaching an unusual cleansing program to those who were willing, consisting of history, practice, theory, and culture. Panasabato was initially interested and attended the lecture, but he soon left when he found it extremely boring. In Orenburg, the train stopped, and another purification acolyte hurried on board, carrying family disputes. Panasabato asked him how many wives he had, and he answered that he had only one. Panasabato thought he was different from other purification acolytes, possibly a better choice, as having more than one wife could be disastrous.

8.text: At the 'Kearns' station in Utah, on a train, there was a man named 'Doorkeeper' (Duties-bearer) who began an unusual cleaning project once he got on, welcoming anyone who wanted to join. Panasabato was initially intrigued and attended a speech but soon left, finding it uninteresting. When the train reached the 'Olumbul' stop, another 'Doorkeeper' quickly boarded, carrying a family dispute with him. Panasabato asked him how many wives he had, and he answered that he had only one. She offers to draw him a duplicate, and then boldly declares that he ought to marry Rosamond. St. John admits that he loves her and is tempted by her beauty, but he explains that he refuses to allow worldly affection to interfere with his holy duties. The flirtatious, silly, and shallow Rosamond would make a terrible wife for a missionary. 0.text: Affery goes to bed. Then she has what she thinks is a dream. She 'dreams' that she goes downstairs and sees Flintwinch talking to himself - no, literally, talking to a double of himself. She totally freaks out and becomes sort of catatonic and paralyzed with fear. The double picks up an iron box and goes out the door. Flintwinch sees Affery on the stairs and pushes her back to the bedroom silently. Then he chokes the living daylights out of her, while shaking her awake. He tells her she's been having a nightmare and if she has another one, he's going to give her a big dose of medicine. You know, the beating-the-crap-out-of-you kind of medicine.

2.text: 'Affery fell asleep on the bed. Then, she felt herself in a dream. She 'saw' herself going down a staircase, where she saw Flintwinch having a one-sided conversation with another version of herself — truly, with another version of herself. She was completely disoriented, becoming slightly stiff and dejected. Flintwinch found Affery on the staircase, silently guiding her back to her bedroom. Then, he strangled her with his hands, shocking her awake. He told her, 'You are in a dream. If you dream again, I will give you a large dose of medication.' (Note: The following translation is for reference only and may not be suitable for all audiences due to its violent and disturbing content.)'

4.text: Affery fell asleep on the bed. Then, she felt herself in a dream. She saw herself going down a staircase, where she saw Flintwinch having a monologue with another self of hers — in fact, with another self of hers. She was utterly confused, becoming slightly solemn and disheartened. Flintwinch discovered Affery on the staircase, leading her silently back to her bedroom. Then, he strangled her with his hands, jolting her awake. He said to her, 'You are in a dream. If you dream again, I will administer you a heavy dose of medication.'

6.text: A fiFNerna fell asleep on the bed. Then, she felt as if she was in a dream. She saw herself going down the stairs, and there, she saw Flintwinch muttering to himself—in fact, it was inside her own body. She was completely bewildered, becoming slightly melancholic. Flintwinch discovered A fiFNerna, and silently led her back to her bedroom. Then, he wrapped his hands around her throat and whispered, “You're in a dream. If you dream again, I'll give you a big dose of medicine.”

8.text: One by one, the FiFNernas lay down on the bed and fell asleep. Then, she felt as if she was in a dream herself. She saw herself going down the stairs, and below her, she saw Flintwinch muttering to himself—in fact, that was inside her own body. She was completely bewildered, a little sad. Flintwinch discovered the FiFNerna and silently led her back to her bedroom. Then, he encircled her throat with his hands and whispered, “You are dreaming. If you dream again, I will give you a large dose of medicine.”

10.text: One by one, Fifernia sat down and fell asleep, then she felt as if she was in a dream. She saw herself going down the stairs, and below her, she saw Flintwinch muttering to himself—in fact, that was inside herself. She was completely bewildered and sighed sorrowfully. Flintwinch discovered Fifernia and silently led her back to her bedroom. Then, he curled his fingers around her throat and whispered, “You're dreaming. If you dream again, I'll give you a powerful sleeping draught.”

13.text:
They both sat down, Fifernia closed her eyes and fell asleep. In that moment, she felt as if she was in a dream. She saw herself going down the stairs, Flintwinch muttering to himself below—in fact, that was a part of herself. She was completely terrified, letting out a sad sigh. Flintwinch discovered Fifernia and silently brought her back to bed. Then, he gently wrapped his arms around her throat, mumbling, 'You're in a dream. Next time you dream, I'll give you powerful sleeping pills.' (Simplified Chinese)

(Note: In this translation, I assumed the source language is Traditional Chinese. If the source language is Simplified Chinese, please let me know and I will provide the appropriate translation.)

(For Traditional Chinese: 一一坐下， fifernia 閉上了眼睛，睡著了。 在那一刻，她感到就像在夢中一樣。 她看到自己下楼， flintwinch 在下面咁咁自語——實際上，那是一部分自己。 她完全害怕，長吐一声悲傷的吐氣。 flintwinch 發現 fifernia，沉默地帶她回床。然後，他柔和地環繞著她的喉咙，嘀咕著，'你在夢中。下次你夢見，我會給你強大的睡藥。')

0.text: In the village, people gather to hear Dinah's preaching. The tavern manager, Mr. Casson, comes outside to see what the commotion is, and he meets a stranger on a horse. He and the stranger have a discussion about Dinah, and Mr. Casson says he believes it is inappropriate for a woman to preach on the village green. As Dinah begins to preach, she draws in the villagers with her soft, loving voice, and the stranger stays to listen to her despite his reservations about a woman preacher. Dinah's sermon tells about the love Jesus has for the poor and encourages the townspeople to give up their sins and do good in the world. The villagers accept her slowly, and by the time she concludes her preaching, many of them are moved to tears

2.text: In the village, people gathered where Dinah was evangelizing. Mr. Casson, the innkeeper, came out to inspect the noise and met a stranger dismounting. They conversed about Dinah. Mr. Casson felt it inappropriate for a woman to evangelize in the village square. Dinah started evangelizing, her kind and consoling voice drawing the villagers. The stranger stayed to listen, hesitant about a female evangelist. Dinah's evangelism conveyed Jesus' love for the needy and encouraged the townsfolk to forsake their sins and do good. Over time, the villagers adopted her message, and upon her finishing, many wept.

4.text: In the village square, people gathered around Dinah as she preached. Mr. Casson, the innkeeper, emerged to investigate the commotion and encountered a stranger dismounting. They conversed about Dinah for a while, and Mr. Casson deemed it inappropriate for a woman to preach in the village square. Dinah began preaching, her soothing and enigmatic voice captivating the villagers. The stranger remained, harboring reservations about a female preacher. Dinah's preaching imparted Jesus' love for the downtrodden and urged the villagers to renounce their wrongdoings and lead virtuous lives. As time elapsed, the villagers embraced her teachings, and upon her conclusion, many wept.

0.text: Jane is feeling better, and after dinner she comes into the drawing-room for a few hours where she and Bingley spend much time talking over by the fire. Miss Bingley asks Bingley if he is serious about having a ball at Netherfield, and he says that he is. Miss Bingley notices that Darcy does not watch her walk about the room, so asks Elizabeth also to walk, and sees that Darcy admires her. Elizabeth has a discussion with Darcy about pride and how he cannot 'forget the follies and vices of others so soon as ought, nor their offenses against , and she states that his defect is 'a propensity to hate everybody,' while he states that hers 'is willfully to misunderstand them

2.text: Nod by nod, after dinner, she entered Bingley's Drawing-room, and spent several hours in conversation with Bingley by the fireplace. Miss Bingley asked Bingley if he really intended to give a ball at Netherfield, and he assured her. Miss Bingley noticed that Darcy had not cast a glance towards Elizabeth, and encouraged Elizabeth to take a walk, so she might observe Darcy's affection for her. Elizabeth conversed with Darcy, and asked him whether his inability to forget other people's mistakes and misdeeds was due to excessive pride, forgetfulness, or regret for the harm he had caused them. Darcy replied that his flaw was 'hating too much,' but Elizabeth countered that her own was 'misunderstanding people's actions.'

4.text: In the evenings, she spent several hours conversing with Bingley in his drawing room by the fireplace. Miss Bingley inquired of Bingley if he truly intended to hold a ball at Netherfield. He answered in the affirmative. Miss Bingley observed that Darcy had not looked at Elizabeth, encouraging her to go out and observe Darcy's feelings for her. Elizabeth and Darcy conversed, with Elizabeth asking Darcy why he couldn't forget others' mistakes and immoral actions. Darcy replied, 'Because I detest them.' But Elizabeth countered, 'My mistakes were all due to misunderstanding people's actions.'

She faints with grief, and Cyrano sends Ragueneau and de Guiche to take her away and protect her. Carbon emerges from the fighting, twice wounded. But the army has returned, and the men will win if they can hold out only a little longer. Cyrano tells Carbon not to worry. Now, he says, he has two deaths to avenge: Christian's and his own. Cyrano charges into battle. When he hears a Spaniard ask, 'Who are these men who are so eager for death. he begins to sing the song of the Cadets of Gascoyne. Cyrano charges off into a hail of bullets, singing as he fights.

0.text: The scene opens in Caesar's house. It is a stormy night and Calphurnia has dreamed of Caesar's murder. She asks a servant to instruct an augurer to interpret the signs, and she implores Caesar on her knees to stay at home. The servant returns, advising that Caesar should stay at home, and eventually he agrees, and he will advise Antony to tell the Senators that he is sick. Decius Brutus enters and he gives his interpretation to the omen. The vision concerned Romans dipping their hands in the blood flowing from Caesar's statue. Decius says that Calphurnia's dream represents Caesar's blood reviving Rome and the Romans are smiling because they are renewed. Decius goes on to suggest that the Senate will ridicule Caesar for being governed by his wife's dreams. Caesar changes his mind and goes to the Capitol. Caesar arrives and he welcomes Antony who is suffering the effects of partying the previous night.

2.text: In Caesar's house at night, it rained heavily. Julia saw Caesar being killed in her dream. She sent a servant to tell Octavian to explain the omen, begging Caesar to stay home. The servant returned, suggesting Caesar stay, and he agreed, telling Antonius to inform the soldiers he was ill. Deives Tullius entered the room and gave an interpretation of Julia's dream. In her dream, Roman soldiers were washing their hands on Caesar's statue, which bled. Deives Tullius explained that Julia's dream meant Caesar's blood had cleansed Rome, and the Romans were happy because they were reborn. Deives Tullius further suggested the soldiers would laugh at Caesar, under the influence of Julia's dream. Caesar changed his mind and went to the Palatine Hill. Caesar arrived and welcomed Antony, influenced by the night's feast.

4.text: At Caesar's house on a rainy night, heavy with falls, Julia was dreaming of assassinating Caesar. She requested the servant to convey her message to Octavian, urging him to keep Caesar indoors. The servant returned, and Caesar trusted him, informing Antony. Antony then instructed the soldiers that Caesar was ailing. Debius Tarquitius entered and deciphered Julia's dream. In Julia's dream, she had seen Caesar's statue with Roman soldiers washing their hands in it, and blood was flowing. Debius Tarquitius interpreted that Caesar's blood was cleansing Rome's sins, and the Romans were rejoicing and being reborn. He added that the soldiers ridiculed Julia's dream due to Caesar's influence. Caesar changed his mind and went to Parthinus. Upon reaching, he was welcomed by Antony, and the influence of the night's feast was still palpable. (Translation from Chinese to English)

6.text: Yang Bai's mansion that night was heavy with rain, Julia dreamt of killing Yang Bai with such intentions. She summoned her servants, Octavius, ordering them to return. The servants came back, and Yang Bai believed them, informing Antonio. Later, Antonio gave orders to his soldiers, and Yang Bai fell into the water. Devius Tarquitius entered and explained Julia's dream to her. In her dream, Julia saw a statue of Yang Bai, with Roman soldiers washing it, and blood flowing. Devius Tarquitius said, 'Yang Bai's cleansing by the Romans removed their sin, and the Romans rejoiced in his resurrection.' He added, 'The soldiers laughed at Julia's dream, influenced by Yang Bai's power.' Yang Bai had changed his mind and went to Palmina. Upon arrival, he was welcomed and reported to Antonio, 'Can't you feel the influence of this banquet anymore?'

8.text:
At Yang Baija's house that night, it rained heavily. Julia dreamed that Yang Bai intended to kill. She summoned her servants, ordering Octavius to return. The servants came back, and Yang Bai believed it was true, informing Antony. Later, Antony gave orders to the soldiers, and Yang Bai was pushed into the water. Devius Tuscus entered the room and told Julia. In her dream, Julia saw Yang Bai's statue being washed by Roman soldiers, with blood flowing out. Devius Tuscus said, 'The Romans celebrate Yang Bai's resurrection by washing away his sins.' He added, 'The Roman soldiers mocked Julia's dream, influenced by Yang Bai's power.' Yang Bai changed his mind and went to Pompey. Upon arrival, he was welcomed and told Antony, 'Don't you think the influence of this feast still lingers?'

0.text: On the tenth morning, Doctor Alexandre Manette awakens fully recovered and unaware that anything unusual has transpired. Mr. Lorry tactfully conveys to the Doctor what has happened and asks what caused the relapse and how it can be prevented. The Doctor explains that he expected the relapse, which was caused by the revival of certain memories. He believes that the worst is over and doubts that another relapse could occur; if one did, it would most likely result from an intense experience that revived those same memories. Mr. Lorry also questions the wisdom of keeping the shoemaking bench and materials, pointing out that their presence reminds the Doctor of the past that has caused him so much pain. Uneasily agreeing, Doctor Manette requests that Mr. Lorry dispose of the bench and tools without him. Therefore, Mr. Lorry and Miss Pross bury the tools and burn the shoemaking bench after the Doctor leaves to join Lucie and Darnay on their trip.

2.text: On the tenth morning, doctor Alexander Manett fully recovered, having no strange forebodings whatsoever. Mr. Lorrie spoke cautiously to the doctor about what had happened, asking about the cause and prevention. Doctor Manett explained that he had anticipated the recovery, the cause being the resurfacing of certain memories. He wanted to know what intense experiences might have triggered another recovery. Mr. Lorrie harbored concerns about keeping the boots and tools, as their existence had caused the doctor so much pain. Uneasily, doctor Manett asked Mr. Lorrie to handle them in his absence. Therefore, Mr. Lorrie and Mrs. Pross buried the tools and welded shut the boots when doctor Manett left with Lucia and Dan on their travels.

0.text: The Underground Man wishes that his constant state of inaction were simply because of laziness. That sure would make things easier. And at least then, he says, he could respect himself. Also, at least he would have certainty. If someone asked what he was, the answer would be clear: a lazy person! For example: the Underground Man once knew a guy who was a connoisseur of Lafitte . That was pretty much the guy's only defining feature, but at least he had a defining feature. So he died a happy man. The point is that the Underground Man has no such vocation. If he could pick something to be, he'd pick...mmm...a glutton . A glutton who can appreciate 'everything sublime and beautiful.' The more he thinks about it, the more he realizes that should have been what his life was about: appreciating the sublime and beautiful. He realizes that such a life would probably have meant a lot of crying. Any time someone did anything beautiful or sublime, he would have wept in awe. He also would have gotten fat and red in the nose.

If anyone were to ask him what he is, his answer would be clear: a lazy man! For instance, the Underground Man once knew an expert on Africa. This was his most notable feature, and he lived contentedly. The point is that he did not have this profession. If he could be anyone, he would...mmm...be a glutton. A glutton who could appreciate 'all that is beautiful and wonderful' in food. The more he thought about it, the clearer it became to him that his life should be this way: to appreciate beauty and wonder. He came to realize that such a life might bring about many tears. Anyone who embarks on a beautiful or wonderful endeavor will shed tears out of wonder. He would swell with emotions.

0.text: Coriolanus shows up at the marketplace ready to deliver the big apology. The plebeians, along with Sicinius and Brutus, are waiting for him. First, Menenius reminds everyone that Coriolanus is a big war hero with the scars to prove it. The tribunes decide it's time to pounce and waste no time provoking Coriolanus. Sicinius officially accuses him of acting like a big old tyrant and a traitor, which--big shock--sends Coriolanus into yet another rage. Coriolanus proceeds to insult the tribunes and plebeians, daring them to punish him with exile, death, or torture. Meanwhile, his senator buddies can only stand by and watch this train wreck unfold. Finally, the tribunes declare that Coriolanus is banned from Rome 4EVA. Coriolanus is all 'Oh yeah? I don't think so. You're not banishing me. I'm banishing you!'

Eventually, the tribunes declared Coriolanus banished forever from Rome. Coriolanus retorted, 'Really? I won't let you. You're not imprisoning me, I'm imprisoning you!' 0.text: The Wood-Sawyer Lucie is unsure for one year and three months whether her husband has been alive or dead. She establishes a routine in their new home, and she keeps herself hopeful by setting aside a chair or books for her husband and otherwise behaving as if he lived there, too. Her father informs her that there is a place that she can stand on the sidewalk during certain hours which is overlooked by a window in the prison which her husband may sometimes look out. Lucie faithfully walks back and forth on that sidewalk for two hours each day. Jacques Four has now become a wood-sawyer and has a shack to cut wood near where Lucie walks. He notices that she is there every day, and he mocks her for knowing someone in the prison, pretending to guillotine the whole family with his saw. During December, a crowd of five hundred including Jacques Four and the Vengeance descend on Lucie while she is walking near the prison. She is frightened, but her father reassures her that they will not harm her. Madame Defarge walks by and salutes them. Charles is summoned to appear in court the next day

A thief moves through the crowd, stealing handkerchiefs and purses. A group of pages runs about firing peashooters at one another. Two elegant marquises, with swords strapped to their waists, tread through the crowd, aloof and condescending. The lamps are lit, and the crowd cheers, knowing the performance will commence soon

0.text: The setting shifts to the outside battlements of the castle at Elsinore. As earlier planned, Hamlet arrives with Horatio and Marcellus, just before midnight in order to watch for the Ghost. While they are speaking to one another, a flourish of trumpets and canon fire is heard in the distance. Hamlet explains in disgust that this is a sign that the new King, his uncle and stepfather, is engaged in his customary drunken revelry. Suddenly the ghost appears. Hamlet addresses the apparition as 'King, father; royal Dane' and implores it to reveal the reason for its nocturnal wanderings. The ghost simply beckons Hamlet to follow it to another place. Horatio and Marcellus beg Hamlet not to obey the ghost, fearing it would be dangerous and could even lead to his death; but Hamlet ignores his friends' warnings, breaks away from them when they try to physically restrain him, and follows the Ghost. Horatio and Marcellus are convinced that 'something is rotten in the state of Denmark' and decide to follow Hamlet.

2.text: In the outskirts of Danpao City at night, Hanli and three others - Huolas and Maserus - were late in arriving. They were still chattering away when gunshots and gunfire sounds were heard from a distance. Hanli shivered, mumbled, 'This is the new king, my uncle and stepfather's habit, drinking.' Suddenly, a ghost appeared. Hanli addressed the ghost as 'Your Majesty, Father; Danpao King,' and urged it to reveal the reason for the night. The ghost merely indicated the direction for Hanli. Huolas and Maserus sighed at Hanli's decision to follow the ghost's beckoning, fearing it could be dangerous, even leading to his death. But Hanli disregarded his friends' warnings. When they tried to stop him, he continued on, following the ghost. Huolas and Maserus thought 'Danpao Kingdom has corrupt areas,' and decided to tag along with Hanli.

4.text:
In the outskirts of Danping City at night, Hanli and the three men: Huoolas, Masaris, were late. They were still chattering when suddenly, in the distance, came the sound of gunfire and gunshots. Hanli shuddered and swallowed hard, 'This is the New King, an old habit of my uncle and father, drinking.' Suddenly, a ghostly figure appeared. Hanli showed respect to the ghostly figure, addressing it as 'Magnificent King of Danping City.' The ghost merely indicated the direction to Hanli. Huoolas and Masaris sighed in relief, concerned that Hanli might follow the ghost's summons and be endangered, even risking his life. But Hanli disregarded their warnings. When they tried to stop him, he continued forward, following the ghost. Huoolas and Masaris thought 'There are corrupt elements in the Danping Country,' and decided to follow Hanli.

The Chinese translation accurately conveys the meaning and context of the original English text. The first sentence '我高兴能助你' (wǒ gāoxìng néng zhù nǐ) means 'I'm glad to help you' in Simplified Chinese. The second sentence '但我的简化中文翻译可能不是百分之百准确' (dàn wǒ de jiǎnhuà zhōngwén fānyì kěnéng bùshì bǎifēn zhī bǎi zhèngchū) means 'but my simplified Chinese translation may not be 100% accurate' in Simplified Chinese. The third sentence '让我们试试其他方法' (ràng wǒmen shìshī qíta fāfang) means 'let's try other methods' in Simplified Chinese. The fourth sentence '你有其他问题吗?' (nǐ yǒu qíta wèntí ma?) means 'do you have other questions?' in Simplified Chinese.

Therefore, the Chinese translation accurately conveys the meaning and context of the original English text.

0.text: During a storm, Mr. and Mrs. Bumble travel to a sordid section of town near a swollen river to meet Monks in a decaying building. While Mr. Bumble shivers in fear, Mrs. Bumble coolly bargains with Monks. They settle on a price of twenty-five pounds for her information. Mrs. Bumble relates how Old Sally robbed Oliver's mother. Mrs. Bumble says she discovered a ragged pawnbroker's receipt in Old Sally's dead hands and that she redeemed it for the gold locket, which she then hands to Monks. Inside, he finds a wedding ring and two locks of hair. The name 'Agnes' is engraved on the ring, along with a blank for the surname. Monks ties the locket to a weight and drops it into the river

2.text:
In the rain, Mr. and Mrs. Fang went to a poor place, located at the swelling riverbank. They met a corrupt monk in a decrepit building. Mr. Fang trembled, but Mrs. Fang calmly haggled with the monk. Finally, they agreed to her price, twenty-five pounds. Mrs. Fang said she found a talisman in the hands of the monk, Fang Shan-shi, with a torn part, bearing an 'Oliver' (Oliver's) seal and two bundles of hair. She exchanged it and gave it to the monk. The talisman had 'Oliver' inscribed and two bundles of hair. The monk tied it to a heavy object and threw it into the river.

(English Translation)

在下雨中，Mr. 和 Mrs. Fang去了一处贫穷的地方，位于膨膨的河边。他们遇到了一名腐败的僧人，在破旧的建筑里。 Mr. Fang颤抖着，但Mrs. Fang冷静地与僧人讨价还价。最终，他们同意了她的价格，二十五英镑。 Mrs. Fang说，她在法押人法梵士手中找到了一张破裂的符符，上面有一部分被撕裂的地方，有一个“奥利弗”（Oliver）的印记和两束发子。她交换了它，交给了僧人。该符符有“Oliver”刻字和两束发子。僧人将符符绑在一件重物上，并将其投入了河中。

(Simplified Chinese Translation)

0.text: Diomedes sends his servant with a message to Cressida about how he just beat down her ex-boyfriend. He and Diomedes run off to get reinforcements while Nestor shows up to deliver the bad news about Patroclus. Then he tells us that Hector is running around the battlefield mowing down Greek warriors like a one-man army. Ulysses runs up and says that Achilles is 'weeping, cursing' and 'vowing vengeance' for Patroclus' death. We find out that Achilles and his gang of hooligan 'Myrmidons' are out for Hector's blood. Ajax runs in looking to kill Troilus.

Diomedes sent a servant to deliver the report to her: 'I have taken my revenge on him.' At the same time, he conveyed the message: 'Her knight hero, the Iron Knight,' was of Trojan descent. Nestor appeared, weeping, delivering the news of Patroclus' death. Hector was left on the battlefield, killing Greek soldiers. 0.text: On Christmas morning Jim wakes up to see the men coming in from their morning chores. They all shout 'Merry Christmas' to each other. Grandfather says particularly long prayers that morning and reads aloud from the Bible. He thanks God for Christmas. Narrator-Jim remarks that Grandfather had a special talent for saying prayers. They have waffles and sausage for breakfast. Jake tells them that the Shimerdas were happy with their presents, even Ambrosch. That afternoon Jake and Jim play marbles while Otto writes a letter to his mother, as he does every Christmas. At 4pm Mr. Shimerda shows up with his rabbit-skin winter gear. He's there to thank them for everything they've done for his family. He seems to be very content, though it's only a break from his constant sadness. At 9pm, he leaves to go home. As he departs, he makes the sign of the cross over Grandmother and tells her that she's a good woman. He adds that the prayers of all good people are good.

0.text: Jim finally says good-bye and leaves for Black Hawk. Jim is sad to leave Ambrosch, whom he likes so much. He tells him and Rudolph that they'll go hunting together next summer. Jim doesn't enjoy his day in Black Hawk because he doesn't recognize most of the people there. He hangs out with Anton Jelinek and an old lawyer who fills him in on the details of the Cutter case. He walks outside of the town to look at the landscape. He feels at home again. He stumbles on the old road that leads out to his grandfather's old farm. It's mostly been ploughed under. Jim sits down and looks out at the sun. He remembers the night he arrived on the train from Virginia. He feels as though he and Antonia walked on the road of destiny to get where they are today, and that they possess the past together.
