0.text: The witches again meet at an open place, this time with Hecate, the goddess of witches, who looks pretty angry. Hecate lays into the weird sisters in a lengthy, rhyming speech that sounds a bit like a nursery rhyme. She's super irritated that they were meddling in the affairs of Macbeth without consulting her first, as she could've done a better job. Also, she points out, Macbeth isn't devoted to them, only to himself. But, fine, Hecate will clean up this mess. She tells them to all meet in the morning, when Macbeth will come to know his destiny, whatever that means. Then there's a catchy witch song and dance, and everyone exits after Hecate. FYI: Some literary critics believe that these scene is way too hokey to be Shakespeare's work, so it must have been added to the play some time between the time the play was first written and its publication in the first folio , which was after Shakespeare's death . A fellow playwright, Thomas Middleton, may have written the snazzy songs in this scene.

2.text:
The witches gathered again, this time with Hecate, the witch goddess, who was extremely angry. Hecate reprimanded the strange sisters in a long, didactic manner, like a nursery rhyme. She was angry that they did not seek her approval before interfering in Macbeth's affairs, believing she could have handled it better. Moreover, she declared that Macbeth was not devoted to them, but to himself. However, Hecate planned to calm the chaos. She instructed them to gather at night, so that Macbeth might learn of his fate, whatever the outcome. Lastly, there was an enchanting witch dance, after which everyone departed, leaving only Hecate. It is worth noting that some literary critics argue that this scene is too contrived and may have been added later by playwright Thomas Middleton.

Translation:

The witches assembled once more, with Hecate, the goddess of witches, in a furious mood. Hecate scolded the peculiar sisters in a lengthy, didactic manner, reminiscent of a nursery rhyme. She was incensed that they did not consult her before meddling in Macbeth's business, convinced she could have managed it more effectively. Furthermore, she announced that Macbeth did not dedicate himself to them, but rather to himself. Nevertheless, Hecate intended to quell the turmoil. She ordered them to meet at dusk, allowing Macbeth to discover his destiny, regardless of the outcome. Eventually, a mesmerizing witch performance ensued, and everyone departed, leaving only Hecate behind. It's important to mention that certain literary critics suggest that this scene is overly manipulated and may have been inserted later by playwright Thomas Middleton.

His personal preference is for Farebrother, who has a humane touch and who has been serving as chaplain all along without pay. Now that the post is an earned one, it seems unfair to deprive him. On the other hand, Bulstrode is Lydgates main backer in the town, where he anticipates serious oppositions to his plans for medical reform. Lydgate, therefore, attends the meeting in a confused state. There is heated discussion much of personal, among the members who have earlier assembled. Lydgate comes in last and finds them equally divided. Ultimately, his casting vote is decided by his smarting ego. Mr. Wrench, an old style medical practitioner, declares that it is well known that Lydgate will vote will Bulstrode. Incensed, Lydgate does just that. So Mr. Tyke becomes the hospital chaplain. Farebrother meanwhile, continues to meet Lydgate with the same friendliness as before. But his skepticism and tolerant attitude dont impress Lydgate favorably.

0.text: Book II, Chapter 6 Carrie accompanies the Gormers to one of their new houses and while there meets George Dorset while taking a walk. He pleads with her to give him some proof of his wife's infidelities, implying that he wants to divorce her and marry Lily instead. Lily becomes afraid and runs away from him, telling him she cannot help. When she returns to the Gormer house, Mrs. Gormer informs her that Bertha Dorset had been there for a visit. Lily head back to the city and finds a place in a hotel, paying more for her rent than she can afford. She is soon visited by Mr. Dorset who implores her to help him out of his situation, but Lily refuses to reveal anything. She then goes to visit Carrie Fisher and finds Rosedale in Carrie's house, most likely invited there so he and Lily could meet. After the dinner Carrie talks with Lily alone, and tells her that in order to defeat Bertha Dorset, Lily will have to either marry Mr. Dorset or marry someone else.

0.text: When Antonia comes to town she is excited to see Jim. She suggests that Grandmother will like her better once she learns to live in town. Jim enjoys having Antonia around again. Mrs. Harlings sees that Antonia stops work a lot to play with the children. She learns more English rapidly. Jim gets jealous because Antonia takes a liking to Charley Harling. She always does things for him like bake him cakes or sew buttons on his coat. Antonia also likes Nina Harling, who is six and very moody. She cries a lot. When Mr. Harling is away, Jim has fun evenings at the Harlings. When he's home, though, everyone has to go to bed early, because Mr. Harling likes a quiet house. He works alone in his study and doesn't pay attention to anyone else. He seems like a very powerful nobleman to Jim. But when he's away, the house of noisy and fun. They have a piano that everyone likes to play, even Mrs. Harling.

2.text:
ANTONIA arrived at the city and was very excited to see the GYM. She believed that once she got used to city life, her grandmother would like her even more. The GYM welcomed ANTONIA warmly. MISS HARING noticed that ANTONIA often stopped to play with the children. She quickly learned English. The GYM was jealous, as ANTONIA began to like CHARLIE HARING. She often helped him, such as baking cakes or mending his coat sleeves. ANTONIA also fell in love with NANCY HARING, who was six but very lazy. She often cried. Mr. HARING's absence made the Harring household lively. However, when he was at home, everyone had to go to bed early because Mr. HARING preferred a quiet household. He worked alone in his study, paying no attention to anyone. He was like a powerful aristocrat, astonishing Jim. But when he was away, the Harring household was filled with noise and entertainment. Everyone, including MISS HARING, played the violin, and everyone enjoyed it.

0.text: The King and Laertes are discussing the crime that has been committed by Hamlet when a messenger arrives bearing a letter announcing Hamlet's impending return. Claudius requests that Laertes help to kill the Prince. Laertes, seeking to avenge his father is all too willing. He plans to poison his sword and use it to slay Hamlet. The king agrees to this plan and says that if it fails, he will give Hamlet a poisoned cup of wine. The Queen enters and announces that Ophelia has drowned. Laertes laments her death and leaves. Claudius tells Gertrude that he has been calming Laertes and that they should follow lest this news cause his temper to flare again.

2.text: Han King and Laertes were discussing Hanjal's errant behavior, suddenly, a messenger arrived, reporting that Hanjal was on his way back. Claudius told Laertes, 'You can go and kill the prince.' Laertes, with his desire for revenge burning strongly, decided to poison his sword, intending to kill Hanjal. Claudius agreed to this plan, adding, 'If we fail, I will give Hanjal a poisoned drink.' The queen entered, announcing Ophelia's suicide. Laertes mourned her death and left. Claudius told Gertrude, 'You have been comforting Laertes, we should have left earlier to prevent rekindling his anger.'

We should leave sooner to prevent his anger from being rekindled.'

0.text: The old neighbor has problems of her own. She's a beggar and a thief, but for now, she's Jimmie's only option. She dispatches Jimmie to buy her a can of beer. Unfortunately, Jimmie's father intercepts him and steals the beer. He can't cope with the 'livin hell' at home either. Jimmie hangs out before returning to the apartment. He can hear his parents fighting, threatening, and perpetrating violence on each other; the neighbors comment on how 'Ol' Johnson' is at it again. Apparently the parents have earned a bit of a reputation for hand-to-hand combat. Jimmie finally gathers the courage to return, and when he does, he finds his drunken parents passed out on the floor. He and Maggie hold each other, quivering and scared, until 'the ghost mists of dawn' arrive.

2.text: The old neighbor had her own issues. She was a bureaucratic woman, but Jimmie now had only one option. She had asked Jimmie to buy her an ice cream. Unfortunately, Jimmie's father intervened and took the ice cream from him. He could no longer endure the situation at home. Jimmie lounged outside and then returned to the apartment. He could hear them quarreling and threatening each other; the neighbors gossiped, 'Old John' had caused trouble again. They were said to have gained a certain reputation for their fights. Jimmie finally gathered courage and, upon his return, found his parents drunk on the floor. He embraced Maggie, trembling and frightened, until the 'morning mist of the soul' descended.

0.text: The Duchess is fetched by the Queens soldier. She appears happy to see Alice and is relieved that she will not be executed. The conversation between the Duchess and Alice is packed with statements and the moral of each of these statements. This is enough to disorient Alice, since she has never thought that everything that she said would eventually have a moral. Frightened by the Queen, the Duchess finally leaves and Alice is now encouraged by the Queen to meet the Mock Turtle. The Queen orders the Gryphon  to take Alice to the Mock turtle. The Mock Turtle, sitting on a little rocky ledge, is sad and constantly sighing. Alice requests the Mock Turtle to tell her, his history. The Mock Turtle very proudly lists the various subjects that were taught to him. The subjects include, Reeling and Writhing and the different branches of Arithmetic . Apart from this were Mystery, Seaography, Drawling, Stretching and Fainting. What excites Alice about the Mock Turtles school is that the duration of attendance would lessen day by day. The Mock turtle asserts that it is 'because of this that they are called lessons'.

2.text: Soldiers brought the queen to fetch Alice. She seemed pleased to see Alice, but her heart wouldn't be fooled. The queen's threats drove the queen away, and after her departure, the queen urged Alice to go see the Mock Turtle. The queen ordered the Gryphon to take Alice to see the Mock Turtle. The Mock Turtle was sitting dejectedly on a stone, sighing. Alice asked the Mock Turtle to share his past. The Mock Turtle boasted about the subjects he had studied. The subjects included Reeling and Writhing, various branches of mathematics. There were also Mystery, Geography, Drawling, Stretching, and Fainting. Alice was most intrigued by the fact that the study time had been reduced. The Mock Turtle claimed, 'Because of this reason, we are called 'Courses'.'

4.text: Soldier brought the queen back, and she seemed quite happy to see Alice, but her heart would not be deceived. The queen's threat caused the queen to leave, and after she left, the queen told Alice to go see the Mock Turtle. The queen ordered the Cheshire Cat to take Alice to see the Mock Turtle. The Mock Turtle was sitting on a stone, sighing. Alice asked the Mock Turtle about his studies. The Mock Turtle boasted about his subjects. 0.text: The Lilliputian emperor is pleased that Gulliver is friendly and cooperative, so he rewards him with some court diversions. The diversions, however, prove to be quite different than one might expect. It is the Lilliputian court custom that men seeking political office demonstrate their agility in rope dancing, among other things. How long and how skillfully a candidate can dance upon a rope determines his tenure in office. Of the candidates, two are particularly adept: Reldresal, Gulliver's friend, and Flimnap, the treasurer. Other diversions include noblemen competing for official favor by crawling under or leaping over a stick, a feat for which they are then rewarded with various colored threads. Gulliver also reviews the Emperor's troops; he stands, legs apart, while the tiny men march through. As a result of Gulliver's cooperation, a pact between Gulliver and the Emperor is agreed on. Gulliver is granted limited freedom on certain conditions. In return for abiding by the conditions, he will receive food sufficient for 1,728 Lilliputians. Gulliver swears to the articles in proper form, and the Emperor frees him.

2.text: King Shihuang enjoyed cooperating with Joliver, so he provided him with entertainment in the palace. However, this kind of entertainment was far from satisfying people's expectations. In King Shihuang's palace, men vying for political positions had to demonstrate agility through activities such as jumping rope or walking on high wires. The length and skill of jumping or walking on high wires determined the duration of the position. Excellent candidates included Joliver's friends arelresal and the finance minister Flimnap. Another form of entertainment was for low-class commoners to crawl or jump over poles for the pleasure of the court and receive various colored ropes as rewards. Joliver also reviewed the Small People Army, standing aside as they came to him. Due to Joliver's cooperation, Joliver and King Shihuang signed an agreement. Joliver was allowed to raise and support 1,728 Small People, and he abided by the conditions. Joliver swore as required, and King Shihuang let him go.

0.text: The Mail On a Friday night in late November of 1775, a mail coach wends its way from London to Dover. The journey proves so treacherous that the three passengers must dismount from the carriage and hike alongside it as it climbs a steep hill. From out of the great mists, a messenger on horseback appears and asks to speak to Jarvis Lorry of Tellson's Bank. The travelers react warily, fearing that they have come upon a highwayman or robber. Mr. Lorry, however, recognizes the messenger's voice as that of Jerry Cruncher, the odd-job man at Tellson's, and accepts his message. The note that Jerry passes him reads: 'Wait at Dover for Mam'selle. Lorry instructs Jerry to return to Tellson's with this reply: 'Recalled to Life. Confused and troubled by the 'blazing strange message,' Jerry rides on to deliver it

2.text: In the evening of the last day of November, in the year seventeen hundred seventy-five, a mail coach advanced towards Tellson Bank in London. This journey was dangerous, as three passengers were forced to dismount and climb a hill. From the fog emerged a rider on horseback, bearing a letter. He asked Jarvis Lorry, an employee of Tellson Bank. Mr. Lorry's companions were alarmed, suspecting they had encountered highwaymen or thieves. But Mr. Lorry recognized the voice of the rider as Jerry Cruncher's, a Tellson Bank employee. Mr. Lorry accepted Jerry's letter. The content of the letter read: 'Wait for the lady at the turnpike.' Mr. Lorry instructed Jerry to return this reply: 'Awakened.' Jerry felt perplexed and uneasy due to the cryptic message, so he continued on his way to deliver it.

4.text:
In the year 777, on the seventeenth day of July, the last night, a mail coach arrived at Tellson Bank in London. The road was dangerous, and three passengers were forced to dismount and climb a hill. From the mist appeared a knight, carrying a letter. He addressed Jarvis Lorry, the Tellson bank clerk, and asked, 'Is this Mr. Lorry?' Mr. Lorry's companion felt fearful, suspecting they had encountered highwaymen. But Mr. Lorry recognized the voice as that of Jerry Cruncher, another Tellson bank employee. Mr. Lorry accepted Jerry's letter envelope. The contents read, 'Wait at the tollgate.' Mr. Lorry instructed Jerry to reply, 'Awake.' Jerry felt perplexed and uneasy about the mysterious message and decided to deliver it further.

0.text: The Governess and Miles, alone at last, speak cagily about Miles's explorations of the grounds over the past day or so, when he's been left to his own devices. Finally, it's time to get everything out in the open. The Governess insists that she's only there to help Miles and to be with him - and he sees that she wants him to tell her everything. As he prepares to confess, she sees for the first time that he's afraid - of her. Miles nervously tells the Governess that he'll tell her anything, but not just now; he says he has to go see Luke . Before she lets him go, the Governess just asks him one thing: did he take the letter she left in the hall yesterday?

0.text: Spring arrives, and Gray Beaver finishes the journey. White Fang is one year old, and next to Lip-lip, he is the largest yearling. He continues to have his battles with other dogs. When he fights with Baseek over a piece of shinbone, White Fang rips Baseeks right ear and wounds him on the shoulder. Baseek, old and weak, gives up. In mid-summer, White Fang encounters Kiche, who has now forgotten him and has had a new litter. She hovers protectively around her litter, trying to drive White Fang away. When White Fang is three years old, there is a great famine in the land. Only the strong will survive, for the Indians eat the weaker dogs. The Indians also eat the soft-tanned leather of their moccasins and mittens to fill their stomachs. White Fang escapes into the forest to hunt on his own, at times robbing rabbit snares and at times capturing small game, like squirrels and woodmice. At the end of the famine, White Fang meets Lip-lip, with whom he fights until Lip-lip is killed. He then returns to the village and is received warmly and given plenty of fish.

0.text: It is a cold, wet November afternoon when the novel opens at Gateshead, the home of Jane Eyre's relatives, the Reeds. Jane and the Reed children, Eliza, John, and Georgiana sit in the drawing room. Jane's aunt is angry with her, purposely excluding her from the rest of the family, so Jane sits alone in a window seat, reading Bewick's History of British Birds. As she quietly reads, her cousin John torments her, reminding her of her precarious position within the household. As orphaned niece of Mrs. Reed, she should not be allowed to live with gentlemen's children. John throws a book at Jane and she calls him a 'murderer' and 'slave-driver.' The two children fight, and Jane is blamed for the quarrel. As punishment, she is banished to the red-room.

2.text:
In a gloomy and sad November afternoon, at Gateshead Hall, Ireby siblings - Elizabeth, John, and Jessica - were seated in the Drawing Room. Jessica, unwilling to be received by Ireby, sat quietly by the window, engrossed in Thackeray's Vanity Fair.

She read in silence, but John teased her, reproaching her as the orphan of Mexico City, she should live with the gentry. John threw a book at her, labeling her as 'murderer' and 'slave driver.' The children quarreled, and Jessica was blamed for causing the quarrel. As a punishment, she was forced to go to the Red Room.

In a November afternoon damp and sad, in the Drawing Room of Gateshead Hall, Elizabeth, John, and the Wasp –– Elizabeth, Isabella, and the Wasp –– were sitting.

She sat in silence, but John sneered at her, scolding her for being an orphan in a Chinese novel, 'Dream of the Red Chamber', and should live as a lady. John threw a book at her, calling her a 'villain' and a 'whip for slaves'. The children were noisy, and the Wasp was blamed for causing a commotion. As punishment, she was forced to go to the Red Room.

As punishment, she was ordered to go to the Red Room.

For future translation suggestions, use pinyin system before Chinese characters to help non-Mandarin speakers pronounce them correctly. For example, '耳濡 (ěr r m)' can be written as '耳濡眼泪 (ěr r m yǎn shuì)'. This way, the Chinese character '泪水 (yǎn shuì)' is clearly explained as 'tears' in English, not 'eye' or 'tea' as in English.

Translation: Your Chinese translation accurately conveyed the meaning and context of the English text. Congratulations! 😊

For future translations, use the pinyin system before Chinese characters to help non-Mandarin speakers pronounce them correctly. For instance, '耳濡 (ěr r m)' can be written as '耳濡眼泪 (ěr r m yǎn shuì)'. This ensures that the Chinese character '泪水 (yǎn shuì)' is clearly explained as 'tears' in English, not 'eye' or 'tea'.

0.text: Cedric is in his home, Rotherwood, impatiently waiting for his servants to come home. He is also displeased that his ward Rowena is late for supper. His thoughts are interrupted by the blast of a horn. Then the gatekeeper announces that Prior Aymer of the Abbey of Jorvaulx, Brian de Bois-Guilbert, and a small party of men are on their way to the royal tournament at Ashby-de-la-Zouche and want to lodge at Rotherwood for the night. Cedric does not want to entertain these Normans, but his Saxon pride demands that they be offered hospitality; however, he clings to his dignity by refusing to go out to welcome them. Only when they come to him in his hall does Cedric reluctantly welcome them. Cedric counsels Rowena against appearing before the guests. He does not trust the Knight Templar and does not want anything to interfere with his plans to marry Rowena off to the right gentleman. She, however, is keen to hear the latest news from the Holy Land from the Palmer, since she is in love with Ivanhoe, whom she thinks is still fighting in the Crusades.

Sir Edward did not wish to receive these Frenchmen, but his Saxon pride demanded they be welcomed; however, he maintained his dignity, refusing to go out and receive them. 0.text: When Emma calls for Harriet at the Abbey Farm, the excited girl tells Emma that she has visited with Martin's mother and two sisters. On the way home, Emma decides to stop at the Westons and is disappointed to find they are not home. As she turns to leave, the Westons arrive in their carriage. They inform Emma that Frank Churchill will be arriving the next day and staying for a fortnight. They assure Emma that they will bring Frank to Hartfield. The next day Mr. Weston and Frank call at Woodhouse. Emma finds Frank to be a very good-looking gentleman of well-bred manners; she is also impressed by his lively spirit. He praises Mrs. Weston for her pretty looks and elegant manners. Emma immediately likes Frank and imaginatively concludes that Frank also has an interest in her. She barely notices that he plans to call on Jane Fairfax next since he already knows her.

2.text: Emma called Harriet from Abbey Farm (Highwood). Harriet came with excited emotions to tell Emma that she had visited Mrs. Weston and her sister. On her way home, Emma thought of stopping by the Weston house, but she found they were not at home. As she was leaving, a carriage appeared from the Weston house. They informed Emma that Frank Churchill would come the next day and stay for two weeks. They promised to bring him to Hartfield. The next day, Weston and Frank Churchill came to Highwood. Emma found him to be a very handsome gentleman with good manners, and she was also drawn to his lively spirit. He paid Mrs. Weston a compliment on her beauty and elegance. Emma grew fond of Frank Churchill and believed that he held similar feelings for her. She overlooked the fact that he planned to visit Miss Fairfax next, as they were already acquainted.

On her way home, Emma thought of dropping by the Westons', but found they weren't there. A car arrived at their house as she was leaving. They informed Emma that Frank Churchill would arrive the same evening and stay for two weeks. They promised to bring him to Hartfield. The next day, Weston and Frank Churchill came to Highwood. 0.text: Five Years Later It is now 1780. Tellson's Bank in London prides itself on being 'very small, very dark, very ugly, very incommodious. Were it more welcoming, the bank's partners believe, it would lose its status as a respectable business. It is located by Temple Bar, the spot where, until recently, the government displayed the heads of executed criminals. The narrator explains that at this time, 'death was a recipe much in vogue,' used against all manner of criminals, from forgers to horse thieves to counterfeiters. Jerry Cruncher, employed by Tellson's as a runner and messenger, wakes up in his small apartment, located in an unsavory London neighborhood. He begins the day by yelling at his wife for 'praying against' him; he throws his muddy boot at her. Around nine o'clock, Cruncher and his young son camp outside Tellson's Bank, where they await the bankers' instructions. When an indoor messenger calls for a porter, Cruncher takes off to do the job. As young Jerry sits alone, he wonders why his father's fingers always have rust on them

0.text: Mr. Lorry arrives at the Royal George Hotel in Dover and after refreshing himself, spends the day pondering on his mission while he waits for the young woman who is Lucie Manette. She arrives believing that there is some property belonging to her late father in Paris, but Mr. Lorry breaks the news to her that her father is still alive. He is Dr. Manette who has been imprisoned in the Bastille in Paris for the last eighteen years. The French authorities have recently released him and as he was one of Tellson's Bank's clients, Mr. Lorry has been sent to identify him. It is hoped that Lucie will take the responsibility for caring for her father and bringing him back to health. Lucie is taken aback at this news and she faints. A large red-haired woman runs into the room pushing Mr. Lorry aside and going to the young lady's assistance using smelling salts and cold water to revive her.

0.text: The Prison Door This first chapter contains little in the way of action, instead setting the scene and introducing the first of many symbols that will come to dominate the story. A crowd of somber, dreary-looking people has gathered outside the door of a prison in seventeenth-century Boston. The building's heavy oak door is studded with iron spikes, and the prison appears to have been constructed to hold dangerous criminals. No matter how optimistic the founders of new colonies may be, the narrator tells us, they invariably provide for a prison and a cemetery almost immediately. This is true of the citizens of Boston, who built their prison some twenty years earlier. The one incongruity in the otherwise drab scene is the rosebush that grows next to the prison door. The narrator suggests that it offers a reminder of Nature's kindness to the condemned; for his tale, he says, it will provide either a 'sweet moral blossom' or else some relief in the face of unrelenting sorrow and gloom

2.text: In the seventeenth century, a desolate and apathetic crowd gathered at the prison gates in Boston's outskirts. Here stood a large oak tree, with iron nails driven into it, marking this place as a site for dangerous criminals. The founders of the new settlement may have had optimistic attitudes, but they still built prisons and cemeteries here, just as the Boston residents had done twenty years prior. The only thing out of place in this scene was a rosebush growing by the side of the prison gate. The author notes that it provided some kind of natural kindness to those sentenced to death, offering 'the sweet petals of virtue' or some relief in the midst of unstoppable sadness and despair.

The only exception in this scene was a rosebush growing by the side of the prison gate. Since the Spanish troops have cut off their supplies, the French have no food. Cyrano seems to be the only one in camp that is not miserable. He is still awake even though most of the cadets are sleeping, for he has just traveled through the Spanish line in order to dispatch a letter to Roxane, as he does everyday. The letters that he writes give him great pleasure.

They lament the French soldiers, surrounded, being disheartened, dejected, and famished. Due to the Spanish troops severing their supplies, the French army is devoid of food. Cyrano is the unperturbed figure in camp. He remains vigilant, despite the majority of cadets slumbering, as he repeatedly traverses the Spanish lines every day to deliver a letter to Roxane. His correspondence brings him immense pleasure.

0.text: In this short scene, Quince and Flute are searching for their missing friend, Bottom. They worry that 'Pyramus and Thisbe' won't be performed without him. Theseus is known for his generosity, and the actors believe they will potentially be rewarded with a lifelong pension for their stellar performance of this play. As they lament this lost opportunity, Bottom suddenly returns. His friends want to hear his story, but Bottom tells them there isn't time for that now: They must prepare for the play. He warns them to avoid onions and garlic so their breath will be sweet for the 'sweet comedy' they will perform.

He advises them to avoid garlic and onions to keep their breath fresh and enhance the comedy's appeal.

0.text: In order to best describe Typee life, the narrator profiles a typical day. Usually, they wake late, after the sun is up. Then they rise and bathe in a nearby refreshing stream. A light breakfast is enjoyed and then pipes are smoked. After breakfast, people tend to whatever they like. Tinor inspects her cloth and food supplies; Marheyo works on his hut; the girls adorn their hair and skin with oils. The narrator usually wanders with Kory-Kory or else sits inside. Then they enjoy a midday nap. Usually in the afternoon, the narrator goes to the Ti, where Mehevi and the other chiefs gather. Since women are not allowed in the Ti, it resembles a happy bachelor pad where the best food can be found and where the men sit around smoking and talking. After night falls, a light evening meal of 'poee-poee,' cooked breadfruit, is eaten. Native girls often dance around their huts under the moonlight. Everyone then sleeps. In general, life with the Typees resembles a continual gentle slumber, with activities in between

women dance under the moonlight, while others have already fallen asleep. Living with the Typee people is like a continuous comfortable dream, filled with various activities.)

In their daily life, the author paints a vivid picture of routine through the description of an ordinary day. They often wake up late in the morning, with the sun already up. After getting up, they take a bath in the nearby clear stream. Following breakfast, a light pipe is enjoyed. Subsequently, people engage in their individual activities: Tonini checks his clothes and supplies; Mahoney works on his house; girls oil their hair and skin. The author typically spends the afternoon with Korako or remains indoors. They then savor a light dinner in the evening. Generally, the author visits Typee in the afternoon, where Mehevi and other chiefs assemble. Since women are forbidden from entering Typee, it is akin to a bachelor's paradise, offering the finest fare, and men gather to smoke and converse. At night, a dinner made with 'poee-poee' (taro) is served. Local women dance under the moonlight, while others have already retired to sleep. Living among the Typee people is like a perpetual comfortable slumber, filled with diverse activities.

0.text: A suspicious Nelly finds out that Cathy has been sneaking away to the Heights during her illness. Nelly forces the truth out of her, and Cathy briefly takes over the narrative. Here's Cathy's story: she goes to the Heights every night while Nelly is sick. She and Linton spend all sorts of time talking and telling stories, finding out how little in common they have. One day, she runs into Hareton, who tries to impress her with the fact that he can now read his own name above the door. She just mocks him and goes into the house. Hareton bursts in and throws a screaming Linton into the kitchen. Linton later blames Cathy for the scene, but they make up. And that's the end of Cathy's narration. Nelly promptly tells Edgar about Cathy's visits to the Heights; again, she is forbidden to go there.

2.text:
Nípò dǎng wèi Cāthy yǒu míxīn, zhǎo xiàn tā mìngqí chū dào gāodì. Nípò pòshū Cāthy, tā gōngrèn shūjīng, tā fènggōng de gūshì: mìngqí tā chū dào gāodì, tā hé Lín dōng duōcháng gōngtóng zhī fù. Yī tian, tā xiàngqǐng Hǎishìqí lǚfū, tā zìshuàng mén shàng yǒu tā míngzì, yǐ shānzài tā. Tā zhǐ xiào le yī huì, jìn rù zhùshì. Hǎishìqí zhāi'ēn Lín dōng, pū qǐ Lín dōng jìn cūn chūn fàn. Lín dōng gǎnzhèng Cāthy, dàn tāmen hèjìe le. Cāthy de gùshì shū'jiè le.

Immediately, Nípò told Hǎishìqí, forbidding Cāthy to go to the high place again.

(Note: In this translation, I assumed the source language is Traditional Chinese, which is used in Taiwan and Hong Kong.)

0.text: Mrs. Bennet and her daughters visit the Lucas Family the day after the Meryton ball to discuss the events of the previous night. Charlotte Lucas has overheard Bingley remark that Jane is pretty and that he likes her very much. Everyone unanimously approves of Bingley, but they are in disagreement about Darcy. Most of the women criticize his standoffish behavior and haughtiness; but Charlotte defends Darcy by saying that his 'pride' is an inevitable corollary to his position in society as a 'fine young man with a family fortune'. Elizabeth agrees with her partially and says that she could have easily pardoned Darcy's pride if he had not affronted hers. Mary philosophically muses about the distinction between 'pride' and 'vanity'. The chapter also gives a brief account of the Lucas family--Sir William Lucas was a tradesman formerly and was knighted when he was a mayor. He is friendly and courteous. His wife is a kind soul, but too dull. They have many children, the eldest of whom is Charlotte, a sensible, intelligent, and practical girl.

2.text: The Bennet family visited the Lucas family's football field the evening after yesterday's event, to discuss what had transpired. Charlotte Lucas admitted to having favorable feelings towards Jane, after hearing Mr. Collins praise her beauty. Everyone praised Collins, but opinions on Darcy varied. Most women criticized him for his aloof and arrogant behavior, but Charlotte defended him, believing his 'self-respect and self-love' were natural traits of a wealthy and distinguished young man. Elizabeth agreed with Charlotte, able only to forgive his self-respect when he had not insulted her. Mary discussed the differences between 'self-respect and self-love' and 'loving oneself.' This chapter also provided a brief description of the Lucas family-- Sir William Lucas, once a merchant, had become the city's lord, receiving a knight title. He was kind and polite. His wife was a good woman, but rather simple-witted. They had several children, the eldest being Charlotte, a clever, intelligent, and practical girl.

Her niece, Miss Rose, is an angelic beauty of seventeen. Mr. Losberne, the eccentric local bachelor surgeon, arrives in a fluster, stating his wonderment at the fact that neither woman is dead of fright at having a burglar in their house. He proceeds to attend to Oliver for a long while. When he returns, he asks the women if they have actually seen the thief. They have not, and, since Giles has enjoyed the commendations for his bravery, he has not told the women that the thief he shot is a small boy. 0.text: Cinna the poet is on his way to attend Caesar's funeral when he is accosted by a group of riotous citizens who demand to know who he is and where he is going. He tells them that his name is Cinna and his destination is Caesar's funeral. They mistake him, however, for the conspirator Cinna and move to assault him. He pleads that he is Cinna the poet and not Cinna the conspirator, but they reply that they will kill him anyway because of 'his bad verses.' With Cinna captive, the crowd exits, declaring their intent to burn the houses belonging to Brutus, Cassius, Decius, Casca, and Caius Ligarius.

Cinnaus was seized, and the crowd dispersed, announcing the intention to burn the houses of Brutus, Cassius, Cassius the Younger, Casius Ligarius, and Decius.

0.text: Now onto the business of summarizing. The author dedicates these idylls to the memory of someone who loved them, speculating that he may find an image of himself in them. This mystery man seems to him just like 'my king's ideal knight,' especially because he followed his conscience above all else and was completely dedicated to one woman. He was faithful to a woman for whom his loss is particularly devastating. Ooh, a clue. Now that he's gone, everyone realizes how great he was. Even though his position on the throne made him especially vulnerable to criticism, he appears blameless. Who could wish for a better life for his only son, or hope for more for his son's sons than that they resemble such an excellent father--Albert the Good? Now the author addresses the widowed queen, telling her to be strong and endure in the memory of the light they two shared. He ends by saying something along the lines of, 'May Albert's love, the love of her children, and the love of her people surround her until God's love reunites her with her husband again.'

He has gone now, and everyone recognizes his greatness. Though he sat on the throne, making him particularly vulnerable to criticism, he remained unblemished. His only child's wish, or perhaps his grandchild's hope, was that they would be better than this ideal father--Abraham. 0.text: The Islet David finds himself on a small islet, cut off from the mainland by a small river. He tries to cross the river, but finds it is too wide and deep. He returns to the shore to get his piece of wood, planning to try and float across, but the yard has floated back out to sea. David is now miserable. He begins eating raw shellfish. Sometimes he manages to keep them down, and other times they make him extremely sick. He is especially depressed because he can see a church and several houses on the mainland, but he knows he cannot cross the river. The next day he sees, to his surprise, a red deer, which he realizes must have swum the river. He also discovers that he has lost all his money after the shipwreck. He sees some fisherman, and wildly hails them from the shore. But, to his shock, they only point and laugh at him. The fishermen return later and, in broken English, reveal to him that the river gets very low at low tide. To his surprise and embarrassment, he finds he can practically hop across the river at low tide

2.text:
David on the island has a vast and deep waterway separating him from the land. He tried to cross it but found it too wide and too deep. He went back to the shore and planned to try floating logs on the water surface, but his barrel was swept back into the sea. David was disappointed. He started eating fried bananas. Sometimes he could swallow them, sometimes they made him feel very nauseous. He was especially disappointed because he could see a hall and several houses on the land, but he knew he couldn't cross the waterway.

The next day, he saw a deer crossing the stream astonishingly. He also found that he had lost all his money while hiding on the boat. He saw a group of fishermen calling him from the shore, but he was surprised to find that they were only laughing at him. The fishermen later reappeared, speaking broken English, and told him that the water level was lower than the ebb tide. He was surprised to find that during the ebb tide, he could practically hop over the river.

0.text: The wanderer. While walking across London, David encounters Mr. Peggotty, who has been to continental Europe in search of Little Em'ly. While Mr. Peggotty is talking to David at an inn, David notices Martha listening just outside the door. Mr. Peggotty heard reports of sightings of Little Em'ly in Switzerland with Steerforth and Littimer, but did not find her. He shows David letters he has received from Little Em'ly, one expressing guilt at the suffering she has caused Mr. Peggotty and Ham, and two containing money. Mr. Peggotty reports that Ham has lost care for his own life and is putting himself forward for many dangerous tasks at sea. Mr. Peggotty goes to an inn where he will spend the night before resuming his search

0.text: Three years have passed. Meg has worked and prepared for the wedding; her sisters and mother have enthusiastically helped prepare Dovecote, the little house where Meg and John will take up residence. Mr. March has recovered his health although not his fortune. He seems to spend most of his time absorbed with his books while the women run the household. John has served some time in the war, been wounded and returned home to recover. Since he has not been allowed to return to the army, he takes a job as an underbookkeeper, refusing Mr. Laurence's offers of help. Jo's position with Aunt March is taken over by Amy whom Aunt March bribes with art lessons. Jo continues to write little romances for the paper while secretly working on a novel. Beth has recovered from the fever but has never regained her strength and remains very frail. Laurie has been attending college to please his grandfather. The chapter ends with Jo admonishing Laurie to be serious during the wedding and avoid behaviors that might cause embarrassment or make her laugh. Laurie tries to flirt with Jo, but she will have no part of romantic notions for herself.

Leon tried to start a romantic relationship with Jo, but she showed no interest at all.

0.text: Adam hopes that Hetty will consent to see him on the morning of her trial, so that she will give up this seeming hardness towards her jailors. Bartle comes back from the beginning of the trial with nothing decisive to report. He says that Hetty's lawyer is good, which is fitting because he has been paid a lot. There are many well-dressed women in the courtroom who stare at Hetty and whisper. Hetty did not speak when asked to plead guilty or not guilty, so her counsel pleaded not guilty for her. Mr. Poyser could barely speak when he was called as a witness, and Mr. Irwine tried to take care of him and accompanied him out of the courthouse. Adam asks if anyone has been there with Hetty, and Bartle says no. Adam decides to come back with the schoolmaster to the courthouse

65.text:
In the courtroom, Hoffstetter spoke passionately to Yarov, but received no response. Yarov's lawyer declared Hoffstetter not guilty. Yarov conveyed some comforting words to Hoffstetter. In the end, they both left the courtroom.

Therefore, Hoffstetter asked Barnaba, who was sitting to his left, and Barnaba agreed. So, Hoffstetter and the defendant entered the courtroom.

(Translation from Simplified Chinese to English)
在法庭上， Hoffstetter 热情地向 Яро夫说话，但得到了无反应。  Яро夫的律师宣布 Hoffstetter 无罪。  Яро夫向 Hoffstetter 传达了些安慰话语。最后，他俩离开法庭。

因此， Hoffstetter 向左边坐着的巴纳巴问了问，巴纳巴同意了。所以， Hoffstetter 与主人入法庭。

(Note: In this translation, I assumed the source language to be Simplified Chinese and the target language to be English. Please let me know if you have any specific requirements regarding the Chinese dialect or English dialect.)

However, the defendant and Hoffstetter passed by the so-called 'Banana Table' as they entered the courtroom together.

(Note: In English, this table is referred to as the 'Banana Table' to distinguish it from banana fruit.)

100.text:
In the courtroom, Hoffstetter spoke many words to Yarov, but Yarov did not answer. Yarov's lawyer declared Hoffstetter not guilty. Yarov spoke a few words to Hoffstetter, consoling him. In the end, they both left the courtroom.

However, they both went up to the 'witness stand' in the courtroom when they entered.

Note: 'witness stand' can be translated as '证人台', but 'witness stand' or 'dock' has no direct Chinese translation, as it is a specific term in English and French law.

The man realized that it was missing and turned to see Oliver running away. The other boys screamed 'stop thief' as the gentleman did and watched as he chased Oliver through the streets. Mary is scared of his sudden energy, and does not think that he is in his right mind; Mr. Featherstone drifts off to sleep, and by the morning he is dead.

It seems that Macbeth seeks an intelligent and compassionate friend like Banquo to be his confidante in crime. Macbeth summons his wife and suddenly finds himself clutching a dagger, which stuns him. Hamlet enters with Rosencrantz and Guildenstern and meets a captain who describes the small and worthless piece of land in Poland young Fortinbras hopes to acquire. Hamlet reflects on the futility of war, bloodshed, and the persistent Poles, who will fight for their worthless land to the bitter end. Rosencrantz and Guildenstern walk ahead, affording Hamlet the opportunity to reflect in solitude. He contrasts his inaction to the aggressive behavior of young Fortinbras, remarking in despair, 'How all occasions do inform against me, / And spur my dull revenge. He is angry at himself for delaying his father's vengeance, especially as he watches nearly twenty thousand men bravely marching to their death for a meaningless piece of land. Hamlet resolves that from now on his 'thoughts  be bloody, or be nothing worth.

0.text: This short scene shifts to the Volscian Senate in Corioli, depicting the Senators engaged in a council of war. They discuss the likely consequences of Romes premature discovery of their preparations for war. Aufidius is irritated by this development and reproaches the First Senator for not keeping the Volscian preparations a closely guarded secret. When the First Senator denies any knowledge of a military leak, Aufidius produces a letter that he had received four days earlier stating that the Romans have raised an army against the Volscians under the leadership of Cominius, Marcius, and Titus Lartius. The letter also states that the Roman citizens are rebelling. To dispel some of Aufidius anger, the Second Senator makes him a general for the battle. Aufidius closes the scene by commenting that if he and Marcius should meet on the battlefield, there is sure to be a fight to death.

The first handsome man denied any relation to the military leak, but Otho showed a letter he had received four days ago. This letter revealed that the Romans had organized a large army, led by Cinius, Marcus, and Quintillius. It also mentioned their rebellion. To appease Otho's anger, the second handsome man appointed him as the military commander. At the end of the scene, Otho declared that if he met Marcus, he would surely encounter a deadly opponent on the battlefield.

0.text: Captain Donnithorne comes in to the dinner, and Mr. Poyser delivers a speech thanking him for all he has done for the tenants and hoping that he will soon come into his inheritance. Captain Donnithorne gives an acceptance speech and then toasts the Squire and Adam. In his toast to Adam, he announces that Adam will be working for the Squire, even though Adam has so far kept this information a secret because he has not yet had a chance to tell Mr. Burge, his employer. Adam gives a proud acceptance speech. Captain Donnithorne walks around the table, greeting the tenants. He does not dare to look at Hetty, who feels slighted

2.text: Captain Donnisan entered. Mr. Poyser expressed to him the farmers' appreciation for all their hard work and his hope that Donnisan would soon inherit. Donnisan agreed, then bowed to the landlord and Adam. While bowing to Adam, he declared that Adam would work for the landlord, even though Adam had not informed George of this and had not had the chance to do so. Adam responded with pride. Captain Donnisan greeted the farmers seated around the table. He hesitated to look at Hetty, and she felt overlooked.

4.text: Adam met the landlord. When Adam saw the landlord, he declared that he would work for him, although Adam hadn't told George this, and hadn't had the chance to do so. Adam answered proudly. Donnisan greeted the farmer sitting next to him at the table warmly. He hesitated, looking towards Harold, but Harold felt neglected.

6.text:
Adam saw the landlord. Upon seeing him, Adam boldly declared, 'I will work for you, sir, despite not having informed George and without your authorization.'

Donnisan paid respects to the farmer seated next to him at the table. He hesitated, casting a glance towards Harold, but Harold felt neglected.

8.text: Donnisan saw the farmer. To the farmer, Donnisan declared courageously, 'Sir, I haven't notified George, and I don't have your permission, but I want to work for you.' (English translation of the given Chinese text)

10.text: Donnisan approached the farmer. Donnisan reasonably declared to the farmer: 'Sir, I haven't informed George yet, and I don't have your consent, but I want to work for you.'

13.text: Karen Three passed by Farmer Sir. Karen Three told Farmer Sir: 'Boss, I haven't told George about this yet, without your approval, but I want to work for you.' (English translation)

16.text: Karen told old farmer Sir, 'Boss, I haven't told George about this matter yet, without your approval, but I want to work for you.'

20.text:
Karen told Sir farmer, 'Boss, I haven't told George about this matter yet, but I want to work under your conditions.'

Translation (Chinese to English): 卡仁告诉Sir farmer，'老板，我还没告诉George这件事，但我想按照你的条件工作。'

Translation (English to Chinese): Karen told Sir farmer, '老板，我还没告诉George这件事，但我想按照你的条件工作。'

English translation: Karen told Sir farmer, 'Boss, I haven't told George about this matter yet, but I want to work according to your conditions.'

0.text: This paper discusses the powers of the states and the federal government to impose taxes on the people. It discusses the notion of concurrent powers and exclusive powers as they relate to taxation. Concurrent powers are those that both the states and federal government share. Exclusive powers are those that only the states or the federal government can exercise. In the case of taxes, the authority of the federal government to levy taxes does not preclude the state governments from doing the same thing since taxation is a concurrent power. The only restriction on the authority of the state governments to levy taxes relates to duties on imports and exports. Congress can levy such taxes, but state governments can only do so with the consent of Congress. Hamilton acknowledges that the concurrent power of taxation could lead to situations in which state governments and the national government impose taxes on the same item, a situation that might be 'inexpedient.' However, Hamilton asserts that the prudence of governments can be relied on to avoid such situations. It is not necessarily a 'direct contradiction of power' for a state government and Congress to impose the same tax.

2.text:
This article discusses the power of both national and federal governments in tax collection. It delves into the concepts of shared power and independent power in taxation. Shared power refers to the power held jointly by the national and federal governments. Independent power refers to the power that can only be exercised by either the national or the federal government. In taxation, the power of the federal government to levy taxes does not prevent state governments from doing the same, as taxation is a shared power. The only restriction on state governments in taxation is related to import and export taxes. The federal Congress can levy such taxes, but state governments can only do so with its approval. Hamilton believes that shared taxing power may result in both the national and federal governments levying the same type of tax, which may be ineffective. However, Hamilton believes that government strategy can prevent such a situation from occurring. National and federal governments levying the same type of tax is not necessarily a 'direct power conflict.'

30.text:
In this article about the Central and State governments' power in taxation, the concepts of shared power and independent power are discussed. Shared power refers to the power that both the Central and State governments hold jointly, while independent power refers to the power each party independently holds. In taxation matters, the State government has the authority to levy taxes within its jurisdiction, as long as the Central government does not infringe upon it, because taxation is a shared power. However, the U.S. Congress can collect these taxes, while the State government can only obtain approval. Gonzalez believes that shared taxation power may lead to both the federal and State governments levying taxes on the same item, but the outcome is uncertain. However, she proposed a strategy to prevent such a situation from occurring. Federal and State governments levying taxes on the same item is not necessarily a power struggle.

(English Translation)
In this article, the concepts of shared power and independent power in relation to taxation between the Central and State governments are discussed. Shared power signifies the power that both the Central and State governments possess jointly, while independent power refers to the power each party independently holds. In taxation matters, the State government has the authority to levy taxes within its jurisdiction, as long as the Central government does not infringe upon it, due to taxation being a shared power. However, the U.S. Congress can collect these taxes, while the State government can only obtain approval. Gonzalez argues that shared taxation power may result in both the federal and State governments imposing taxes on the same item, but the outcome is unpredictable. Nevertheless, she suggested a strategy to prevent such a situation from arising. Federal and State governments imposing taxes on the same item is not inherently a power struggle.

40.text: This article discuses the taxing power relationship between central and local governments. Joint power refers to the power that both the central and local governments co-hold, while independent power signifies the power each side exclusively holds. In taxation matters, local governments have the authority to levy taxes within their jurisdiction, and the central government does not encroach upon this power since taxation is a joint power. Nevertheless, the US Congress can collect these taxes, while local governments can only secure approval. Gonzalez posits that joint taxing power might result in both federal and state governments imposing taxes on the same item, leading to unexpected outcomes. However, she suggests a strategy to address the power conflicts between the federal and state governments in this regard.

50.text: This article discuses the power dynamic between central and local governments in taxation. In taxation issues, local governments have the authority to levy taxes within their jurisdiction, which the central government acknowledges as a joint power. Nevertheless, the US Congress can collect these taxes, while local governments can only secure approval. Gonzalez posits that joint taxation powers could lead to both the federal and state governments imposing taxes on the same item, resulting in unexpected consequences. However, she proposes a solution to resolve power disputes between the federal and state governments in this area.

65.text: This article discusses the power relationship between central and local governments in taxation. There are joint powers, representing the common ownership of both central and local governments, and independent powers, representing the sole ownership of each party. In taxation, local governments have the authority to collect taxes within their jurisdiction, which is considered a joint power by the central government. However, the US Congress can collect these taxes, while local governments can only obtain approval. Gonzalez asserts that joint tax powers may lead to both federal and state governments taxing the same item, resulting in unexpected outcomes. Nevertheless, she proposes a solution to address the power struggle between federal and state governments in this domain.

Gonzalez believes that the existence of shared taxation powers could lead to both the central and local governments imposing taxes on the same item, resulting in unintended consequences. However, she recommends resolving the conflicts between the central and local governments over shared taxation powers.

However, she supports resolving disputes between central and local governments through shared taxing power.

Nevertheless, she advocates for employing shared taxing power to address conflicts between central and local governments.

0.text: Mehevi and the other chiefs seem slightly angry at Tommo after Marnoo leaves. Even Kory-Kory appears to bear him a small grudge. Tommo now has been in the valley for about two months and his leg feels so well that he moves around easily. One day he makes a small 'pop-gun' out of bamboo for a six-year old boy, which shoots items out when one blows on it. The boy is fascinated. Soon after, groups of men and women appear and beg Tommo to make more. He does so, and they all run around like children playing with the guns. Their excitement continues for almost ten days. Tommo stops wearing the shoes that he brought from the ship and he ties them in his bundle near the roof. One day Marheyo suggests interest in them and Tommo gives them to him. Marheyo starts wearing the shoes on a strap around his chest, as a bizarre necklace. The Typees do not work very frequently, but one task with which most women assist is the making of the cloth, or 'tappa. Tappa making involves boiling branches from trees and stretching fibers. The process is described in full

2.text: Mei Hewei and other elders were somewhat angry with Tomi, and even KORY-KORY seemed to harbor some resentment towards him. Tomi had lived in the valley for nearly two months, and his legs had healed. One day, he made a bamboo arrow gun for a six-year-old boy, which shot objects when blown by the wind. The boy was very interested. Soon, many people gathered there, asking Tomi to make more. He obliged, and they all played happily. Their interest lasted for nearly ten days. Tomi stopped wearing the shoes he had brought from the ship and placed them by the bed. One day, Marrupuro expressed interest in their craft, and Tomi gave them the shoes. Marrupuro wore them on his chest, resembling a strange necklace. Commonly, women were responsible for weaving, also known as 'tatting.' Weaving involved cutting tree branches, soaking them in water for several days to soften them, boiling them until the bark softened and could be easily removed, extracting and cleaning the fibers, and then dividing them into bundles based on length and thickness. The bundles were then transformed into a strong, flexible rope, which was used to make a loom, a wooden frame with adjustable pressure rods. The warp threads, which ran vertically on the loom, were fixed by the pressure rods and front and back rods. The weft threads, which ran horizontally, were passed through and crossed over the warp threads, using one thread.

4.text: Mei Hewei and other elders felt anger towards Tomi, and it seemed that KORY-KORY harbored some resentment towards him. Tomi had lived in the valley for about two months, and his legs had healed. One day, Tomi made a bamboo arrow and bow for a six-year-old boy. This bamboo arrow would shoot objects when agitated by the wind. The boy was very interested. Soon, many people gathered there, asking Tomi to make more. He agreed, and they happily played for nearly ten days. Tomi wore shoes brought from the boat by the bedside. One day, Marupru expressed interest in their craft, and Tomi made shoes for him. Marupru wore them around his chest like a strange necklace. Commonly, women were responsible for weaving, also known as 'sewing.' Weaving involved cutting down tree branches, soaking them in water for several days to soften the bark, baking the bark to make it easy to strip and clean the fibers, then dividing them into bundles based on length and thickness differences, and finally turning them into a strong, flexible rope, used to build ladders, frames, and adjustable pressure poles. The vertical lines of the ladder were fixed by the pressure poles and the front and rear poles, while the horizontal lines were secured with a single string line, passing horizontally through the ladder and crossing the vertical lines.

0.text: Emma mourns the departure of Leon. Gloom pervades her thoughts over the loss, and romanticism colors her vision, as she makes him into 'a taller, handsomer, a more delightful, and a vaguer Leon. ' With the passage of time, her passion dims, and 'the black days she had known at Tostes  again. ' She becomes unpredictable, given to strange whims. Charles' mother only makes things worse. In the midst of Emma's depression, Rodolphe Boulanger, a wealthy bachelor and landowner, calls on Charles when one of his servants needs urgent medical treatment. Boulanger sees Emma as she helps her husband and notices her sensuousness. Attracted to Emma, he wonders how to get rid of his present mistress.

0.text: Jude starts looking for a job in Christminster, and as soon as he is offered one , he accepts it. By night he studies sincerely. He spends his money on books, pens and paper even though he cannot afford a fire. When it is too cold, he sits up reading wrapped in a greatcoat, hat and woolen gloves. He persuades his aunt to send him the portrait of Sue and she does so, but reluctantly, and with a warning not to contact Sue. But Jude learns that Sue is working in an ecclesiastical goods shop and eventually discovers her there one day at work. He does not introduce himself to her. Later, she passes him by on the street. He notices her elegance and sophistication in contrast to his own rustic ways. He still does not speak to her and resolves not to think of her except as a relative.

2.text:
Zhu Da started looking for a job at Cristoforo after leaving Zhudan not long ago. He got the job and accepted it right away. In the evening, he seriously studied, buying books, pens, and paper with his money, although he didn't buy fire, but still did so. When it was cold, he wore clothes, hats, and coats, sitting next to the table reading. He asked his grandmother to send him a photo of Su, and she gave it to him, unwillingly, and warned him not to contact Su. However, Zhu Da found Su in a curio shop that day and saw her. He didn't introduce himself to her, but later saw her on the street. He noticed her elegance and culture, which was quite different from his rough exterior. He still didn't speak, deciding to only regard her as a relative.

Translation:

Zhu Da began searching for a job at Cristoforo shortly after leaving Zhudan. He obtained employment and accepted it immediately. In the evening, he studied diligently, purchasing books, pens, and paper with his money, even though he didn't buy fire. When it grew cold, he donned clothes, hats, and coats, sitting beside the table to read. He requested his grandmother to mail him a photograph of Su, and she complied, albeit reluctantly, and cautioned him against contacting Su. Nevertheless, Zhu Da encountered Su in a curio shop that day and saw her. He didn't introduce himself, but later ran into her on the street. He was struck by her refinement and sophistication, which stood in stark contrast to his uncultured appearance. He remained silent, choosing instead to view her as a kin.

4.text: Zhū Dá had not been in Zhūdān for long when he started looking for work in Cristoforo. He soon obtained a position and reported for duty. When it was cold, he wore clothes, hats, and coats, sitting beside the table to read. He asked Grandma to send him Su's photograph, which she agreed to, but reluctantly, and warned him against reaching out to Su. However, Zhū Dá ran into Su at the Curio shop that day, and saw her. He didn't introduce himself, but later bumped into her on the street. He was struck by her elegance and beauty, which stood in stark contrast to his rough appearance. He kept quiet and treated her as kin.

0.text: After the combats of the first day at Ashby, the crowds eagerly await the events of the next day. The excitement reaches a fever pitch when the Disinherited Knight is attacked simultaneously by Athelstane, Front-de-Boeuf, and Bois-Guilbert. With the help of another mysterious character, the Black Knight, who comes to his aid, Ivanhoe overcomes his challengers, emerging the victor once again. After the victory, the Black Knight disappears. Rowena crowns the Disinherited Knight, who is now forced to raise his visor and show his face. He is revealed to all as Ivanhoe, Cedrics son. Severely wounded, he faints at Rowenas feet.

2.text: After Asiasi's first battle, Sedgwick's crowd was anxiously awaiting what would happen next. Excitement reached its peak when the Desert Knights were attacked by Atreus, the Fat Calf, and Poyisgob, shocking their emotions to the core. Following this, another mysterious figure - the Black Knight - appeared and helped Sedgwick, the earl, win once again. After the battle, the Black Knight disappeared. Liana placed a crown on him, and the Desert Knights appeared, forcing him to take off the mask, revealing himself as Sedgwick's son and heir, the earl. He was severely injured and fainted before Liana.

4.text: After the battle at the twenty-first milepost, Sedgwick's followers were anxiously awaiting the next event. Excitement reached its peak when Sedgwick, Duke of Atlus, was attacked by Arturus, the Fat Ox, and Pozidon. Their emotions were struck to the core. The battle ended, and another mysterious figure appeared - the Black Knight - who helped Sedgwick, Duke of Atlus, win again. The Black Knight disappeared after the battle. Then, Lenna donned the crown and the Desdes Knight appeared, forcing him to take off the mask, revealing himself as Sedgwick, Duke of Atlus's child and heir. He was severely injured and fainted before Lenna.

6.text: In the battlefield beyond the twenty-first 'li,' Sade Goke's followers eagerly anticipated the next event, their emotions reaching a peak. When Sade Goke, Duke of Atarus, was attacked by Arturus, the Fat Cow, and Pozidon, their spirits were demoralized. After the battle ended, another mysterious figure appeared - the Black Knight - who helped Duke Atarus win again. The Black Knight disappeared after the fight. Then, Lenna donned the crown, and the Desdes army appeared, forcing him to remove his mask, revealing him as Duke Atarus' descendant. He was seriously injured and fainted before Lenna.

8.text: Twenty-one li away from the battlefield, Sadé's followers were emotionally turbulent, their feelings reaching a peak. When Sadé, Atarus (the fat cow) and Pozidon attacked Sadé, the Duke of Atarus, their spirits were suppressed. After the battle ended, a mysterious figure appeared - the Black Knight - who helped Sadé, the Duke of Atarus, win. The Black Knight disappeared after the fight. Then, Lenna put on a crown, and the Desdes army appeared, forcing him to remove his mask, revealing him as the heir to the Sadé dukedom. He was seriously injured and fainted in front of Lenna.

10.text: Three miles away from the battlefield, Sadé's retinue was deeply moved, reaching the peak of emotions. Three miles from the battlefield, Sadé's companions were deeply moved, their emotions reaching a peak. In Gourville's handwriting, the letter informs Fouquet that a white horse is ready to bear him to safety. The Fouquet destroys the note. Fouquet goes in to see the King. The King asks after his health. Fouquet makes one last attempt to clear his name and defend himself. A little while into their conversation, it is clear Fouquet needs to go to bed. The King summons D'Artagnan to escort the man. Fouquet refuses, saying that a simple footman would do. Once Fouquet leaves, the King orders that D'Artagnan follow him. He asks D'Artagnan to arrest Fouquet, then orders a bunch of draconian measures like a special carriage to prevent notes being thrown out the window. D'Artagnan admits to the King that he tried to save Fouquet, but says that now he will execute his orders. D'Artagnan leaves the King. As he leaves, he sees a very cheerful Gourville heading to Fouquet's lodgings.

0.text: Determined to fight off her depression, Eustacia decides to go to a 'gipsying,' or dance, in East Egdon. Envious of the young people dancing, and later, surprised by Wildeve's presence there, she consents to dance with her former lover and enjoys it more than she can understand. Allowing Wildeve to walk part way home with her, she encounters Clym and Venn, though Wildeve leaves her before Clym can see him. Sure he has seen Wildeve with Eustacia, Venn hurries to the inn and learns from questioning Thomasin that it was her husband. Thereupon, Venn keeps watch on Clym's house and on several occasions frustrates Wildeve's loitering outside the house and trying to communicate with Eustacia. Venn also calls on Mrs. Yeobright, urging her to establish relations with both Clym and Thomasin for the good of all. She decides to forgive Clym and call on him. At the same time, Clym tells Eustacia he must do something to improve relations with his mother.

Before leaving, Lin Wen-bin gave it a gift named 'Nina'. Lin Wen-bin was concerned 'Mas' had learned of their interaction and asked about his marital status. Rosas Square impeded the relationship between the European entity and 'Mas'. At the same time, the European entity confided in Rosas Square about its emotional difficulties and mother-child relationship issues.

0.text: Chapter 33 jumps backwards in time a bit. Cathy and Hareton grow closer, though the sight of it annoys both Joseph and Heathcliff. Together they plant a garden, but dig up Joseph's plants to do it. When Heathcliff scolds them for touching the property, Cathy stands up for herself, saying, 'You shouldn't grudge a few yards of earth for me to ornament when you have taken all my land!' . She also accuses Heathcliff of robbing Hareton of his land and money. Heathcliff storms out. He returns later to find Hareton and Cathy reading together. Unexpectedly, Heathcliff does not fly into a rage. Instead he confesses to Nelly that he has lost interest in revenge. 'hen everything is ready, and in my power, I find the will to lift a slate off either roof has vanished!' . Heathcliff continues to be struck by Hareton's resemblance to Catherine. But then, everything reminds him of Catherine. He tells Nelly that he is a changed man. He no longer has the will to live but yearns for only one thing.

2.text: Chapter thirty-three, let us recall the past for a moment. Cathy and Heathcliff have grown apart, but both Joseph and Heathcliff were enraged by this. They worked the land together, but ruined Joseph's crops. When Heathcliff reprimanded them for encroaching on his land, Cathy stood up to answer, 'Why do you blame us for decorating a few acres of land for myself? You have already taken away all my land, all my wealth!' She also accused Heathcliff of taking away Hatter's land and wealth. Heathcliff became furious and left. Later, he found Cathy and Hatter studying together. Surprisingly, Heathcliff did not fly into a rage. Instead, he told Nelly, 'Everything is prepared. I can no longer tear down a single brick from their house!' Heathcliff was still deeply influenced by Cathy, but all these events reminded him of Cathy. He told Nelly, 'I have become a new man. I have only one thing left.'

4.text:
still deeply influenced by Cathy, but these events reminded him of her. He told Nelly, 'I have become a new man. I have only one thing left to do.'

(Translation: In Chapter Thirty-Three, let us review that Cathy and Heathcliff have parted ways, yet both Joseph and Heathcliff were filled with rage. While working together in the field, they destroyed Joseph's crops. When Heathcliff reprimanded them for encroaching on his land, Cathy rose to defend: 'Why do you accuse us of adorning certain areas for ourselves? You have already taken away all that was mine – my land, my fortune!' She further implicated Heathcliff for seizing Hatter's land and wealth. Heathcliff stormed off. Later, he discovered Cathy and Hatter engrossed in their studies. It was peculiar and startling that Heathcliff did not lose his temper. Instead, he informed Nelly: 'All preparations are in order. I can no longer tear down another brick of their house!' Heathcliff's memories of Cathy remained strong, and he shared with Nelly: 'I am now a changed man. I have but one task remaining.')

6.text: Chapter thirty-three, let's review, Cathy and Heathcliff have separated, but both Joseph and Heathcliff were filled with rage. Working on the same piece of land, they destroyed Joseph's crops. When Heathcliff accused them of taking his possessions on some land, Cathy countered: 'Why do you accuse us of stealing from you in some places? You have taken me – the land, the wealth!' She also accused Heathcliff of taking Hatter's land and wealth. Heathcliff became enraged and left. Later, he found Cathy and Hatter deeply engrossed in their studies. It was strange that Heathcliff did not lose control. Instead, he told Nelly: 'Everything is ready. I can no longer destroy their house's other brick!' Cathy's memory still lingered in his heart, and he confided in Nelly: 'Now, I have become a new person. I only have one task left.'

8.text: Chapter thirty-three, Cathy and Heathcliff had parted ways, but both Heathcliff and Joseph were filled with anger. On the same piece of land, they destroyed Joseph's harvest. When Heathcliff accused them of stealing his possessions at some place, Cathy retorted, 'Why are you accusing us of stealing your things there? You took them from me – the land, the wealth!' She also accused Heathcliff of taking Hatter's land and wealth. Heathcliff left in a rage. Later, he found Cathy and Hatter deeply engrossed in their studies. Instead of losing control, Heathcliff told Nelly, 'Everything is ready now. I can no longer destroy their house with more bricks!' Cathy's memories still lingered in his mind, and he confided in Nelly, 'Now, I have become a new man. I have only one task left.'

0.text: Ellen, distressed by Edgar's refusal to console Isabella, went to visit her at Wuthering Heights. She told Isabella and Heathcliff that Catherine would 'never be what she was' and that Heathcliff should not bother her anymore. Heathcliff asserted that he would not leave her to Edgar's lukewarm care, and that she loved him much more than her husband. He said that if he had been in Edgar's place he would never have interfered with Catherine's friendships, although he would kill the friend the moment Catherine no longer cared about him. Ellen urged Heathcliff to treat Isabella better, and he expressed his scorn and hatred for his wife. He said Isabella knew what he was when she married him: she had seen him hanging her pet dog. Isabella told Ellen that she hated Heathcliff, and he ordered her upstairs so he could talk to Ellen. Alone with her, he told her that if she did not arrange an interview for him with Catherine, he would force his way in armed, and she agreed to give Catherine a letter from him

2.text: She went to see Isabelle in Wuthering Heights because Egbert had refused to console her. She told Isabelle and Heathcliff that 'she would never be the same person for Catherine again.' Heathcliff declared that he would not let Catherine fall into Egbert's loving arms, and declared his love for her exceeded that of his wife. He said if he were in Egbert's place, he would never interfere with Catherine and Isabelle's friendship, but if she no longer cared for him, he would kill that friend. He urged Heathcliff to be kinder to Isabelle, and expressed his desire to free himself from the jealousy and hatred towards his wife. He told her that Isabelle knew what he was, and that she had seen her beloved pet taken away from her neck when she married him. Isabelle told her she disliked Heathcliff, and he commanded her to give him a letter to deliver to Catherine. Alone with her, he told her that if she did not arrange a meeting between them, he would use force, and she agreed to give him that letter.

4.text: She went to see Isabelle at Wuthering Heights as Egbert refused to comfort her. She informed Isabelle and Heathcliff, 'I have become the person once again who was Catherine's, but I can never be that person again.' Heathcliff announced that Catherine would never enter Egbert's embrace, and expressed his love for her surpassing that of his wife. He stated, if he were in Egbert's position, he would never interfere with Catherine and Isabelle's friendship, but if she still loved him, he would abandon that friend. He urged Heathcliff to be more compassionate towards Isabelle and expressed his longing to be freed from the desire to complain and envy his wife. He revealed to her that Isabelle was aware of his true nature and had witnessed the incident of her falling at the wedding and the theft of her dog chain. Isabelle informed her she didn't like Heathcliff, and he asked her to write him a letter, which he then gave to Catherine. Alone with her, he told her if she didn't arrange their meeting, he would use force, and she agreed to give him that letter.

6.text:
She fell down at her wedding and stole her necklace with the ID tag, Isabelle told her that she didn't like Heathcliff, he asked her to write him a letter, and she gave it to him. A person was with her, he told her if she didn't arrange their meeting, he would use force, she agreed to give him that letter.

Translation:

She gave him a letter that she had written to Heathcliff, despite his not liking him. At their wedding, she fell down and had her ID tag necklace stolen. He had threatened her, telling her that if she didn't arrange their meeting, he would use force.

English translation: You're correct, I'm sorry! The meaning and context are preserved in the translation.

Chinese translation: 您翻译正确，对不起！意思和上下文在翻译中保留在位。

50.text: In English, the translation for 'You're wrong' is 'You're mistaken' or 'You're incorrect'. In Chinese, it is '你错了' (Nǐ chū le). Therefore, the Chinese phrase '你错了' (Nǐ chū le) can be translated to English as 'You're mistaken' or 'You're incorrect'.

0.text: The group spends the night around a fire in the desolate ruins of the fort. They eat bear meat for dinner. Looking out at the lake, Heyward hears noises. Uncas explain that wolves are prowling nearby. Hawkeye is pondering the meaning of paradise when he hears another sound. Uncas goes to investigate, and the group hears a rifle shot. Chingachgook follows his son, and those left behind hear a splash of water and another rifle shot. Chingachgook and Uncas return calmly. When Heyward asks what happened, Uncas shows him the scalp of an Oneida. After discussing the plan for the next day, the group falls asleep

2.text: This group of people lit fires around the ancient ruins for dinner, their meal being bear meat. Heydar heard the sounds of the lake shore, Uncas told him that a wolf was hiding nearby. Heydar pondered the meaning of the heavens in his ears, and then he heard another sound. Unis went to investigate, and those left behind heard the sound of a gun, followed by the sound of water and another gunshot. Unis and Cingachgok returned peacefully. Hewward asked what had happened, and Unis showed him the head of a familiar person. After discussing the plans for the next day, they all went to sleep.

4.text: This group of people had their dinner of bear meat around the ancient ruins, with fires lit. Heidar heard sounds by the lake shore; Uncas informed him that a wolf was hiding nearby. Heidar contemplated the meaning of the sky, and then he heard another sound. Unis went to investigate, and those remaining heard gunshots, water sounds, and another gunshot. Unis and Cingachgok returned safely. Hewward inquired about the events, and Unis showed him a head that was familiar to him. They discussed the plans for the next day, and everyone retired to their beds.

6.text:
This group of people held a feast around the ancient ruins, with fires burning brightly. Heidar heard a sound by the lake; Uncas told him that a wolf was hiding nearby. Heidar pondered the meaning of the sky, then heard another sound. Unis went out to investigate, and the rest of the people heard gunshots, water sounds, and another gunshot. Unis and Cingachgok returned safely. Hewward asked some questions about the event, and Unis showed him a familiar face. They discussed plans for the next day, and each person returned to their bed.

Translation: 这群人在古迹附近举办了熊宴，火光照耀盛大。heidar 在湖边听到了一系列声音；Uncas告诉他，一个狼在附近藏着。heidar 思考了天空的意义，再次听到了一系列声音。Unis出去调查，其余人听到了枪声、水声和另一枪声。Unis和cingachgok安全地返回。hewward问了几个关于事件的问题，Unis显示了一张熟悉的脸。他们讨论了下一个日子的计划，每个人回到了他们的床。
